<title>Open thread for night owls: At anti-corruption summit, U.S. told it must end its tax 'hypocrisy'</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/NXQlNp6zklQ/-Open-thread-for-night-owls-At-anti-corruption-summit-U-S-told-it-must-end-its-tax-hypocrisy</link>
<description><p><strong>Nadia Prupis</strong> at <em>Common Dreams</em> writes—<a href="http://commondreams.org/news/2016/05/12/london-summit-us-must-end-tax-hypocrisy-or-corruption-will-prevail" target="_blank">London Summit: US Must End Tax 'Hypocrisy' or Corruption Will Prevail</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
<p>If the U.S. does not end its "hypocrisy" and hold itself to the same tax transparency standards as other nations, efforts to reform offshore secrecy will fail, leaders of the UK's overseas territories <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/tax-transparency-efforts-fail-american-states-excluded-summit">warned</a> at the global anti-corruption summit in London on Thursday.</p>

<figure class="image-captioned width-sm align-right"><img alt="Ghost_Owl_2.jpg" src="http://images.dailykos.com/images/120819/large/Ghost_Owl_2.jpg?1453405089" title="Ghost_Owl_2.jpg">
<figcaption></figcaption>
</figure>

<p>The comments—from leaders of the Cayman Islands, Bermuda, and the Isle of Man—came as U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry told those gathered at the summit, "Corruption, writ large, is as much of an enemy [as terrorism], because it destroys nation states, as some of the extremists we are fighting or the other challenges we face."</p>

<p>The summit follows a massive leak of documents known as the <a href="http://commondreams.org/tag/panama-papers">Panama Papers</a> which exposed how the world's elite use offshore tax havens to hide their wealth, including British Prime Minister <a href="http://commondreams.org/news/2016/04/07/revealed-david-cameron-intervened-eu-crackdown-tax-havens">David Cameron</a>, who hosted the conference.</p>

<p>Cayman Islands Premier Alden McLaughlin slammed states such as Delaware—where a majority of U.S.-based shell companies are situated—and said it was "time to put behind us the shades of hypocrisy that have been part and parcel of global discussion of this issue for years and years."</p>

<p>"So long as countries with real commitments on the world stage continue to focus on jurisdictions that are smaller in size while ignoring the larger jurisdictions, the results will be continued failure," McClaughlin said. "This is going to be a complete disaster if you insist that most places in the world have to conform to a particular standard, and you leave principally the United States and a couple of other rogue nations completely out of it. Because all the shady business is going to migrate to Delaware, Wyoming, Panama, you name it." [...]</p>

<p>For its part, the Obama administration last week<a href="http://commondreams.org/news/2016/05/06/why-and-why-now-panama-papers-john-doe-steps-out-shadows"> announced new rules</a> that would require financial institutions to verify the beneficial owners of any entity that uses the institution's services. The Treasury Department also proposed a <a href="https://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2016/05/06/president-obamas-efforts-promote-financial-transparency-and-combat-corruption-what">rule</a> that would require certain foreign-owned companies to obtain tax identity numbers from the U.S. Internal Revenue Service (IRS), which means they would have to report ownership and transaction information to the agency.</p>

<p>But anti-corruption and tax policy experts said the measures fell short of true reform. "The measure includes a loophole that could well perpetuate the problem of anonymous shell companies," said Gary Kalman, the executive director of the Financial Accountability and Corporate Transparency (FACT) Coalition. "The loophole is dangerous if exploited by terrorists, human traffickers, and corrupt foreign dictators to launder their money through the U.S. financial system."[...]</p>
</blockquote>

<p class="AlignCenter"><strong><a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/05/12/1525807/-High-Impact-Posts-May-11-2016" target="_blank">HIGH IMPACT STORIES</a> • <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/05/13/1525963/-Top-Comments-the-Books-by-Friends-edition" target="_blank">TOP COMMENTS</a></strong></p>

<p class="AlignCenter"><strong>TWEET OF THE DAY</strong></p>

<div class="dk-editor-embed center-block" data-twitter-content='&amp;lt;blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en"&amp;gt;&amp;lt;p lang="en" dir="ltr"&amp;gt;The Robin Hood Tax on &amp;lt;a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/Wall?src=hash"&amp;gt;#Wall&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Street will raise $300B annual to pay for &amp;lt;a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/college?src=hash"&amp;gt;#college&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; for all and so much more! &amp;lt;a href="https://t.co/1hHypwdURE"&amp;gt;pic.twitter.com/1hHypwdURE&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;— Robin Hood Tax (@RobinHoodTax) &amp;lt;a href="https://twitter.com/RobinHoodTax/status/730902933257084928"&amp;gt;May 12, 2016&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/blockquote&amp;gt;'>

<p class="AlignCenter"><strong>BLAST FROM THE PAST</strong></p>

<p>At Daily Kos on this date in <strong>2011—</strong><a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2011/05/12/975181/-Barney-Frank-Recess-appointment-likely-for-CFPB-job%22" target="_blank">Barney Frank: Recess appointment likely for CFPB job</a>:</p>

<div class="table-wrapper">
<table cellpadding="5%" style="border:1px dashed black" width="96%">
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p>Republicans have made killing the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau a primary goal in their efforts to undo everything President Obama and Democrats managed to accomplish in the first two years of his term. To that end, Senate Republicans have vowed to filibuster any candidate for the CFPB unless the agency is gutted and made essentially powerless.</p>

			<p><span>In the wake of that threat, Rep. Barney Frank, co-author of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street reform bill that became law last year, says </span><a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/11/us-financial-regulation-cfpb-idUSTRE74A5FJ20110511?feedType=RSS&amp;feedName=politicsNews&amp;utm_source=feedburner&amp;utm_medium=feed&amp;utm_campaign=Feed%3A+Reuters%2FPoliticsNews+%28News+%2F+US+%2F+Politics+News%29"><strong>it's likely</strong></a><span> President Obama will make a recess appointment to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.</span></p>
			</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>
</div>

<item>
<title>Trump won't release his tax returns? Fine, give him the birther treatment. Good for the goose ...</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/rWINP6hSQrc/-Trump-won-t-release-his-tax-returns-Fine-give-him-the-birther-treatment-Good-for-the-goose</link>
<description><p>Apparently the presumptive Republican nominee is not going to release any of his tax returns. “<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5NNOrp_83RU" target="_blank" title="">Nothing to see here, move along,</a>” is his attitude. He doesn’t think voters are interested. Voters have a funny way of making that decision for themselves, of course. By way of contrast, Hillary Clinton’s tax <a href="https://www.hillaryclinton.com/tax-returns/" target="_blank" title="">records </a>dating back to 1977 are already a matter of public record.</p>

<p>The way to deal with this is for our side to put the word out that Trump is lying about his wealth. We must make him either release the returns to prove the rumors false—in which case, mission accomplished—or, if he doesn’t, double down by citing his continued refusal as a confirmation that the rumors are true.</p>

<p>This needs to become something the media doesn’t stop talking about, like the swift-boating of John Kerry, for example. I don’t advocate such an approach lightly, but they were perfected by Trump and his birther acolytes, so, screw him, to be frank.</p>

<p>Moreover, we should specifically highlight the birther tactics as part of spreading these rumors about Trump’s actual wealth. Doing so not only justifies what we are doing—in politics, turnabout is fair play, after all—but it also reminds people of the fact that Trump was the biggest figure in a disgusting, bigoted movement that, without merit, sought to discredit the Americanness of the first African American president. This can be a double whammy. Trump lied about President Obama and it looks like he’s lying about his own wealth, among so <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2015/12/donald-trump-politifact-truth-lies-217048" target="_blank" title="">many </a>other documented lies. We have to ask: What else is he lying about?</p>

<p>Donald Trump has already shown that he fights dirty. Democrats need to be <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9ALcqt6GMhM" target="_blank" title="">prepared </a>to do what is necessary to make sure that our next president isn’t a fascist. Simple as that.</p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=rWINP6hSQrc:s37Ea0gOhPw:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/rWINP6hSQrc" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Ian Reifowitz)</author>

<title>One out of five plants to leave the planet</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/YKrhumDPnpY/-One-out-of-five-plants-to-leave-the-planet</link>
<description><p>And no, not on little green rocket ships. The plants aren’t going anywhere ... they’re just going.</p>

<p>When we think about extinction, we usually think about animals. Something furry. Something cute. Something with big brown eyes whose plight touches us... as we drive past in our SUVs.</p>

<p>But it’s not just polar bears and rhinos in the crosshairs of the big human-generated extinction event. <a href="http://www.motherjones.com/environment/2016/05/climate-change-plants-hope-jahren-inquiring-minds" target="_blank">Our greenery is also getting less diverse</a>.</p>

<blockquote>
<p><span>The planet's vegetation—from grasslands to deserts to tropical rainforests—is being hit hard by human activity. And deforestation, pollution, agriculture, and climate change are all playing a role.</span></p>
</blockquote>

<p>Climate change hits plants hard with changes in growing season, conditions, and rainfall. It also brings diseases and parasites, such as allowing insects to spread into high altitudes. And plants have one big disadvantage when it comes to dealing with rapid climate change: they can’t run away. Relocation may be difficult for an elk, but it’s impossible for an elm tree.</p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=YKrhumDPnpY:bQgBVmrazyQ:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/YKrhumDPnpY" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Mark Sumner)</author>
<category>Botany</category>

<item>
<title>Ohio's Republican senator makes massive $15 million ad buy</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/GGd9RysFong/-Ohio-s-Republican-senator-makes-massive-15-million-ad-buy</link>
<description><figure class="image-captioned width-sm"><a href="https://secure.actblue.com/contribute/page/dkforts?refcode=20160512LCthermometer&amp;tandembox=show" title=""><img alt="Goal Thermometer" src="https://secure.actblue.com/x/object/actblue-badges/page/dkforts/thermometer/dark.png"></a>

<figcaption></figcaption>
</figure>

<p>Ohio Republican Sen. Rob Portman is clearly <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/rob-portman-ohio-ad-buy-223112" target="_blank">not taking re-election for granted</a>, and he has the money to do a whole lot of not taking it for granted. </p>

<blockquote>
<p><span>The Ohio Republican is launching a shock and awe campaign that plows $14 million into statewide television advertising and $1 million into YouTube programming, a total that former Ohio Gov. Ted Strickland (D) may struggle to match. Portman is one of the most prodigious fundraisers in the country and had $13.4 million on hand at the end of March, while Strickland had $2.7 million.</span></p>
</blockquote>

<p>The Koch brothers are <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/04/14/1515324/-Ted-Strickland-the-Kochs-number-one-target-this-cycle" target="_blank">already spending</a> against Strickland, but Strickland is still keeping pace with Portman, according to <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/05/02/1522233/-Ohio-s-Strickland-and-Portman-tied-for-Senate-seat-but-voters-want-a-Garland-hearing" target="_blank">a recent poll</a> from PPP which shows the race tied at 38 percent. One big challenge for Portman will be that Ohio voters want to see the Senate vote on Merrick Garland, President Obama’s choice to replace Justice Antonin Scalia on the Supreme Court, and Portman is part of the Republican blockade against such a vote.</p>

<p><a href="https://secure.actblue.com/contribute/page/dkforts?refcode=20160512LC&amp;tandembox=show" target="_blank" title="">Please give $3 to help send Ted Strickland to the Senate. The future of the Supreme Court could depend on it.</a></p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=GGd9RysFong:WO35q5lVbMI:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/GGd9RysFong" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>

<item>
<title>Trump cranks up the fundraising machinery</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/FcmBqfSdVVY/-Trump-cranks-up-the-fund-raising-machinery</link>
<description><p>Some people have this idea that running for president is expensive. For example, Bernie has already raised more than $185 million. Hillary has raised about the same amount, with superPACs standing by to add another $76 million. Expectations are that the general election phase will be much more expensive, with the Democratic candidate expected to burn through something like President Obama’s record $1.1 billion effort.</p>

<p>But hey, not everyone has to spend the big bucks. In winning the Republican primaries, Donald Trump had an outlay of only $44 million. That’s a little more than half of what Ted Cruz ran through. It’s only two-thirds of what Ben Carson spent (attention, FEC: If there was ever a “where did that $68 million go” worth investigating). </p>

<p>Trump isn’t shy about explaining how his campaign can fly around on only the best jets, have only the best campaign locations, and <a href="http://mediamatters.org/video/2015/10/13/donald-trump-ive-spent-nothing-on-ads-because-o/206115" target="_blank">still do it on the cheap.</a></p>

<blockquote>
<p><span>I've spent zero on advertising because you and Fox and all of the others, I won't mention names, but every other network, I mean they cover me a lot, to put it mildly.</span></p>
</blockquote>

<p>Yeah. That must be nice. Plus, Trump’s vaunted “self-funding” is actually in the form of a loan he gave himself, a loan that can always be paid back later, should Trump’s campaign gather in funds from elsewhere. Which is exactly <a href="http://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2016-05-04/in-reversal-donald-trump-to-seek-donations-to-fund-campaign" target="_blank" title="">what he's doing</a>.</p>

<blockquote>
<p>Donald Trump’s presidential campaign is building a finance operation that will raise money for the general election, two people familiar with the plan said. ...</p>

<p>Despite some conflicting emotions about their controversial new presumptive nominee, Republicans are already lining up to open their wallets to help the billionaire businessman.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Don’t you worry—the billionaire boys club will be there for Trump.</p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=FcmBqfSdVVY:oRRR4Zi6Nf4:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/FcmBqfSdVVY" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Mark Sumner)</author>

<item>
<title>Planned Parenthood wins a legal battle in Missouri and launches another in Ohio</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/vHWUr5Av0qo/-Planned-Parenthood-wins-a-legal-battle-in-Missouri-and-launches-another-in-Ohio</link>
<description><p>Planned Parenthood won a court victory in Missouri on Wednesday, the same day that it sued the state of Ohio. The fact that the previous sentence refers to court battles in two different states over two different laws attacking Planned Parenthood says a lot about the broader war on women’s health care in Republican-controlled states. </p>

<p>Missouri officials <a href="http://bigstory.ap.org/article/27aec0ddcf084b88a3b23e6593b7bffe/federal-judge-rules-favor-missouri-planned-parenthood" target="_blank">had tried to take away a Planned Parenthood clinic’s abortion license</a> the same day its doctor lost hospital privileges, without giving the clinic a chance to come back into compliance with the requirement.</p>

<blockquote>
<p>The agency's actions "likely were the result of political pressure being exerted by Missouri legislators and the Department's perception that if it did not act in accordance with the legislature's desires, its budget would be cut," [U.S. District Judge Nanette] Laughrey said in the ruling.</p>

<div></div>

<p>She went on to say that "disparate treatment" of the clinic "cannot be justified by political pressure or public opposition." She ordered that the license cannot be revoked before its expiration in June.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Political pressure? You think? Meanwhile, in Ohio, Planned Parenthood is suing to block a <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/02/22/1489146/-Kasich-signs-yet-another-Ohio-law-attacking-Planned-Parenthood-and-women-s-health" target="_blank">law signed by Gov. John Kasich</a> in February that blocks funding for organizations that provide abortions, even though the funding is for services completely unrelated to abortion. The lawsuit <a href="http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/planned-parenthood-sues-ohio-law-strips-funding-39040599" target="_blank">charges retaliation</a>, which is kind of undeniable, as is the fact that the law’s ultimate effect will be to make it harder for low-income women to get care.</p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=vHWUr5Av0qo:41EBZluEg5o:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/vHWUr5Av0qo" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>

<item>
<title>Federal charges filed against police officer in Walter Scott shooting case</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/7J1w12nFiLY/-Federal-charges-filed-against-police-officer-in-Walter-Scott-shooting-case</link>
<description><p>North Charleston police officer Michael Slager was indicted by a federal grand jury this week on charges that include violating civil rights law and lying to investigators. The decision to charge Officer Slager in federal court is an unusual one, and may signify a new way of ensuring that law enforcement officers are held responsible for their criminal acts.</p>

<p>Last year, Slager, who is white, shot unarmed black man Walter Scott five times in the back as he was running away from the officer. Scott had been stopped for a broken tail light and ran after he was unable to provide documentation for the car.</p>

<p>From the<em><a href="http://www.postandcourier.com/20160511/160519884/walter-scott-family-attorney-federal-charges-against-michael-slager-could-be-a-turning-point-in-history" target="_blank" title=""> Post and Courier</a></em>:</p>

<blockquote>
<p>Chief among Slager’s three charges is a count of deprivation of rights under color of law. Public officials are barred under federal laws from using their powers to violate personal “rights, privileges or immunities.” The indictment alleges that Slager was acting with his authority as a policeman when he used unreasonable force — a violation of the Constitution — by shooting Scott five times from behind.</p>

<p>He also was indicted on counts of using a firearm in a violent crime and obstruction of justice. He’s accused of misleading state investigators by saying he fired as Scott came at him with his own Taser; a video showed Scott running away.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Ninth Circuit Solicitor Scarlett Wilson, head prosecutor in the state case, supports federal involvement.  </p>

<blockquote>
<p>“The civil rights aspect of the killing of Walter Scott has always been important,” she said in a statement. “It is essential that law enforcement and our community see the federal government address such an important aspect.”</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Slager can be tried in two courts for the same incident without violating his constitutional right against double jeopardy, since they are in separate and sovereign jurisdictions. These charges provide an opportunity to hold Slager responsible, even if he is found innocent in state court.</p>

<p>Scott's family noted the larger importance of the indictment.</p>

<blockquote>
<p>“This is history,” <a href="http://www.postandcourier.com/20160511/160519884/walter-scott-family-attorney-federal-charges-against-michael-slager-could-be-a-turning-point-in-history" target="_blank">said</a> Chris Stewart, a Scott family attorney. “It could be a turning point in history that the federal government is no longer going to sit on the sidelines. They’re going to make police officers face federal justice.”</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Meanwhile, Slager's lawyers blamed past wrongdoings by law enforcement and the political climate for the indictment.</p>

<blockquote>
<p>“It seems very extreme, and the timing is very interesting,” the statement said. “It really feels as if officer Slager is carrying the burden of many past cases that were handled differently.”</p>
</blockquote>

<p>If convicted, Slager faces a possible life sentence.</p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=7J1w12nFiLY:3p3vHHsE9Es:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/7J1w12nFiLY" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Josie Duffy)</author>

<item>
<title>North Carolina mom of transgender teen on HB2: 'This bill is emotionally killing our children'</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/88Mb6Nb3HVU/-North-Carolina-mom-of-transgender-teen-on-HB2-This-bill-is-emotionally-killing-our-children</link>
<description><p><span>Hope Tyler of Raleigh <a href="http://www.newsobserver.com/news/politics-government/politics-columns-blogs/under-the-dome/article76951512.html" target="_blank">offered a glimpse</a> of the human cost of HB2 on Wednesday, when she said it was “painfully obvious” that Gov. Pat McCrory never thought about the consequences the bill would have on transgender kids. (Yes, Pat, <em>all</em> the children matter in responsible governance, not just the ones you prefer.) Tyler, the mother of a transgender son, teared up at times as she revealed during a press conference that her son had “comfortably begun to settle in” to his identity until passage of the statewide law requiring transgender individuals to use the bathroom that matches the sex assigned to them at birth.</span></p>

<p><span>“This bill is emotionally killing our children and it must be repealed,” she concluded. Here’s a partial transcript (with video below):</span></p>

<blockquote>
<p><span>"In the short time that Pat McCrory decided to pass HB2, it’s painfully obvious that he did not think about how this would affect our transgender children. Calls doubled into suicide hotlines from the trans community. This fact was presented to Gov McCrory in a letter signed by more than 200 mental health care workers.</span></p>

<p><span>From here in North Carolina alone to the transgender children all over the United States, you need to know that you are loved and that change is coming…</span></p>

<p><span>Fifteen years ago, I gave birth to a beautiful blue-eyed blond-haired little girl who never liked dolls or girl’s clothes. By eight, she was the only girl on her flag football team and she was awesome. Age nine, 10, and 12 were filled with years of anxiety attacks only remedied by trips to the ER. Therapist after therapist couldn’t figure out my daughter’s issue until age 12, on the day puberty hit. My daughter collapsed in the closet and could not feel her legs. She was diagnosed with conversion disorder—that is when you are so emotionally traumatized that your body loses all feeling in the arms and legs. My daughter said that she felt trapped in her body…</span></p>
</blockquote><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=88Mb6Nb3HVU:-4uCepjLU6Y:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/88Mb6Nb3HVU" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Kerry Eleveld)</author>

<item>
<title>By big margins, GOP voters falsely believe unemployment and the stock market are worse under Obama</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/SuM7x1U-dvU/-By-big-margins-GOP-voters-falsely-believe-unemployment-and-the-stock-market-are-worse-under-Obama</link>
<description><p>Public Policy Polling continues its groundbreaking scientific research into finding out what Republican voters are forever going on about. We haven't yet been able to open a stable portal to the Republican voter dimension, but we are learning <a href="http://www.publicpolicypolling.com/pdf/2015/PPP_Release_National_51116.pdf" title="">more about it</a>!</p>

<blockquote>There continues to be a lot of misinformation about what has happened during Obama's time in office. 43% of voters think the unemployment rate has increased while Obama has been President, to only 49% who correctly recognize that it has decreased. And 32% of voters think the stock market has gone down during the Obama administration, to only 52% who correctly recognize that it has gone up. <strong>In both cases Democrats and independents are correct in their understanding of how things have changed since Obama became President, but Republicans claim by a 64/27 spread that unemployment has increased and by a 57/27 spread that the stock market has gone down.</strong>
</blockquote>

<p>Our task here, should we choose to accept it, is to interpret that little oddity. So do Republican voters believe unemployment has gone <em>up</em> on Obama's watch simply because they don't like Obama and presume everything is worse under him, or do they not like Obama because they falsely believe unemployment has gone up and are therefore blaming him?</p>

<p>Hmm. We know people who watch Fox News are gloriously uninformed about whatever "issues" Fox News chooses to pontificate on. Perhaps this is mere side effect of the leading Republican news outlet enforcing a strict partisan code of stupidity?</p>

<p>Or maybe two-thirds of Republican voters have a pretty good idea that unemployment is not in fact worse, but are just saying so anyway? Because reasons?</p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=SuM7x1U-dvU:TnR3ylCy93Y:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/SuM7x1U-dvU" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Hunter)</author>
<category>BarackObama</category>
<category>Conservatives</category>
<category>Polling</category>
<category>Republicans</category>

<item>
<title>EPA announces final rule to control methane emissions from new oil and gas wells, more to come</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/0VXa066SX-U/-EPA-announces-final-rule-to-control-methane-emissions-from-new-oil-and-gas-wells-More-to-come</link>
<description><p>The Obama administration on Thursday <a href="https://www.epa.gov/newsreleases/epa-releases-first-ever-standards-cut-methane-emissions-oil-and-gas-sector" target="_blank">announced</a> its final rule governing methane emissions from new oil and gas wells. These are the first rules targeted at methane, which has a “global warming potential” 86 times greater than carbon dioxide over a 20-year period and, because it moves out of the atmosphere much faster than CO<sub>2</sub>, a global warming potential 34 times greater than CO<sub>2</sub> over a 100-year period. <span>The new rule also calls for reductions in volatile organic compounds like benzene, well known as a potent carcinogen. Technical information on the rule <a href="https://www3.epa.gov/airquality/oilandgas/methane.html" target="_blank">can be read here</a>.</span></p>

<p>The rule is part of a larger plan that seeks to cut methane emissions from the U.S. gas and oil sector by 40 to 45 percent over its 2012 levels by 2025. By the end of this year, the Bureau of Land Management is slated to cut methane emissions from oil and gas drilling and hydraulic fracking on public lands. That’s only a small proportion of overall gas and oil production, however.</p>

<p>The rule does not affect existing wells. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency is working on another rule dealing with those, but this won’t be completed until well after President Obama leaves office in January. All this matters in terms of implementing the Paris climate agreement, under which the United States has committed to reducing its overall greenhouse gas emissions 26 to 28 percent by 2025. </p>

<p>EPA Administrator Gina McCarthy stated:</p>

<blockquote>
<p>Today, we are underscoring the Administration’s commitment to finding commonsense ways to cut methane—a potent greenhouse gas fueling climate change—and other harmful pollution from the oil and gas sector [...] Together these new actions will protect public health and reduce pollution linked to cancer and other serious health effects while allowing industry to continue to grow and provide a vital source of energy for Americans across the country.</p>
</blockquote><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=0VXa066SX-U:E8JDGWBeSyA:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/0VXa066SX-U" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>

<title>Russ Feingold hits opponent again over bogus Koch attack</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/tgEvn1Vgar4/-Russ-Feingold-hits-opponent-again-over-bogus-Koch-attack</link>
<description><figure class="image-captioned width-sm"><a href="https://secure.actblue.com/contribute/page/dkforrf?refcode=20160512JM1thermometer&amp;tandembox=show"><img alt="Goal Thermometer" src="https://secure.actblue.com/x/object/actblue-badges/page/dkforrf/thermometer/dark.png"></a>

<figcaption></figcaption>
</figure>

<p>The Koch brothers have picked a fight with former Sen. Russ Feingold, current candidate for his old seat, that they just keep losing. They've already had <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/05/09/1524738/-Koch-brothers-attack-on-Russ-Feingold-backfires-as-local-tv-stations-pull-deceptive-ad">one deceptive ad pulled</a> by Wisconsin television stations in which they accuse Feingold of ignoring a whistleblower's 2009 report of problems with overprescription of opioids at the Tomah VA Medical Center that led to the preventable deaths of several veterans. The problem for the Kochs is that the memo was never sent to Feingold. </p>

<p>The Kochs <a href="http://www.jsonline.com/blogs/news/378686971.html">recut the ad</a> to try to keep the accusation alive, but are still lying. This time they're showing a memo from 2008 that has a handwritten notation saying it was hand delivered to Feingold (no indication that it was received), but that memo doesn't have anything to do with the opioid problem—instead it accuses the hospital's then-chief of staff, David Houlihan, of creating a hostile work environment. </p>

<p>What they keep doing with these deceptive ads is opening up Sen. Ron Johnson, the Republican they're backing, to further attacks from Feingold. Because, as Feingold happily continues to point out, Johnson’s staff <em>did</em> receive the memos about the painkillers and the dead veterans and Johnson has admitted that they were ignored. And he has a really lame excuse for it. That's the focus of yet another <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=75vRu0LybSw">ad from the Feingold campaign</a>, talking about how the ad from the Kochs was pulled, and featuring a Wisconsin vet who says "on veterans, Ron Johnson is not telling the truth." (Watch the whole ad below the fold.)</p>

<blockquote>Narrator: "On Tomah, it was Johnson who failed. Veteran complaints changed hands from one Johnson aide to another in a congressional black hole. Johnson just made excuses."
<p>Johnson: "had this not occurred during an election cycle… when there's an awful lot of turnover… when people are looking at doing job interviews and stuff…"</p>
</blockquote>

<p>It's that "and stuff" that is really the killer here.</p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=tgEvn1Vgar4:MxRAA1jN1vg:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/tgEvn1Vgar4" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Joan McCarter)</author>

<title>Immigration activists deliver taco salads to GOP lawmakers in honor of #TrumpsParty</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/RUvIuVX4l2U/-Immigration-activists-deliver-taco-salads-to-GOP-lawmakers-in-honor-of-TrumpsParty</link>
<description><p><span>Taco salads aren’t just for Donald Trump anymore. They just happened to be on the menu in the House cafeteria Thursday when Trump and Paul Ryan were trying <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/stories/2016/5/12/1525821/-Paul-Ryan-and-Donald-Trump-talk-the-talk-about-unity-but-Ryan-still-doesn-t-endorse-Trump" target="_blank">to be all kissy-kissy</a>, so immigration activists made sure all the key GOP congressional members could partake in one of the most racist Trump schemes to date: <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/stories/2016/5/6/1523909/-The-Taco-Bowl-tweet-was-the-most-racist-olive-branch-of-the-year" target="_blank">operation Hispanic outreach</a> (aka #TacoGate). </span></p>

<p><span>Senate targets included GOP leadership and all the 2016 favorites: Sens. Richard Burr, Rob Portman, Pat Toomey, John McCain, Roy Blunt, Kelly Ayotte, Chuck Grassley, Mitch McConnell, Ron Johnson, John Cornyn, Mark Kirk, and Cory Gardner.</span></p>

<p><span>Some House members, including Speaker Paul Ryan, also got the taco treatment, which included a message saying Latino and immigrant voters would “never forget” who stood with Trump.</span></p>

<p>Democratic Rep. Luis <span>Gutiérrez had some fun with Taco Salad Thursday from the House floor, saying, “The Republicans love the Hispanics so much that they put taco salads on the menus so that we can honor the love and affection that their presidential nominee feels for each and every one of us: The Hispanics!”</span></p>

<p><span>​Video below:</span></p>

<p><a href="https://secure.actblue.com/contribute/page/upgradethesenate2016?refcode=20160505KE1?tandembox=show" target="_blank"><span>​Please donate $3 to turn the Senate blue. The future of the Supreme Court depends on it.</span></a></p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=RUvIuVX4l2U:qEOG8K0i_Ek:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>

<item>
<title>Radio ad ties McCain to Trump on immigration, boosting Democrat Ann Kirkpatrick</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/WfB0agSiOLA/-Radio-ad-ties-McCain-to-Trump-on-immigration-in-boost-to-Democrat-Ann-Kirkpatrick</link>
<description><figure class="image-captioned width-sm"><a href="https://secure.actblue.com/contribute/page/dkforak?refcode=20160512KEthermometer&amp;tandembox=show"><img alt="Goal Thermometer" src="https://secure.actblue.com/x/object/actblue-badges/page/dkforak/thermometer/dark.png"></a>

<figcaption></figcaption>
</figure>

<p><span>Donald Trump’s repeated racial slurs and promises of mass deportations aren’t going to do Sen. John McCain any favors with Arizona’s Latino voters. And just in case they have forgotten who wanted to “<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r0lwusMxiHc" target="_blank">complete the danged fence</a>” in 2010, People for the American Way is out with a new radio ad linking McCain and Trump, <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/politics/first-draft/2016/05/12/radio-ads-in-arizona-use-donald-trump-to-criticize-john-mccain/?smid=tw-nytpolitics&amp;smtyp=cur&amp;_r=0" target="_blank">reports</a> Carl Hulse.</span></p>

<blockquote>
<p><span>In a new Spanish-language radio ad to begin airing on Thursday, the liberal advocacy group takes Mr. McCain and Senator Jeff Flake, Mr. McCain’s fellow Arizona Republican, to task for refusing to act on President Obama’s nomination of Judge Merrick B. Garland to the Supreme Court.</span></p>

<p><span>“Is it because they want to see Donald Trump — the man who called Mexican immigrants rapists and drug dealers — get to name our next Supreme Court justice?” the announcer asks in the ad that will run for a week on Spanish-language stations in the state. The radio spot goes on to say that the senators need to “stop doing Donald Trump’s bidding.”</span></p>

<p><span>The ad appears to be the first aimed specifically at Latinos over the court vacancy and Mr. Trump.</span></p>
</blockquote>

<p><span>And it surely won’t be the last, as Democratic Rep. Ann Kirkpatrick gives John McCain what he’s called “<a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/trump-latinos-mccain-222810#ixzz48T38hWaH" target="_blank">the race of my life</a>.”</span></p><div class="feedflare">

<title>Company tricked mentally impaired victims of lead paint out of settlements</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/NZxrDfeo6kA/-Company-tricked-people-damaged-by-lead-paint-out-of-settlements</link>
<description><p>There’s scum, there’s dirty rotten scum, and <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/social-issues/company-that-reaped-millions-from-deals-with-baltimores-lead-poisoning-victims-violated-law-authorities-say/2016/05/11/051a2bb0-1701-11e6-aa55-670cabef46e0_story.html" target="_blank">there's these guys.</a></p>

<blockquote>
<p>A Chevy Chase company that reaped millions of dollars from deals with poor, disabled victims of lead-paint poisoning in Baltimore has been accused of committing fraud and deceiving court officials, according to a lawsuit filed this week by the Maryland attorney general’s office.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>You’ve probably seen the ads offering to buy structured settlements for a one-time up-front payment. Like taking the cash option on the lottery, selling a settlement can provide a larger payment to meet immediate needs, but it does so at a cost. A big cost. The reason those ads are so prevalent is that companies that buy out settlements generally pay out less than a quarter of the full value of the settlement.</p>

<p>That’s bad enough when it’s a company coming after a worker desperate to make ends meet after being disabled by an on-the-job accident. But it’s even worse when the target is people who got settlements expressly because they were victims of a problem that left them unable to work through the details of what they’re being offered.</p>

<blockquote>
<p>The civil suit alleges that Access Funding violated state law when it aggressively pursued scores of mentally impaired lead-poisoning victims, persuaded them to sell the settlements they received in personal injury lawsuits for a fraction of their worth and then withheld vital information from the courts that approved the deals.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>They “aggressively pursued” mentally impaired victims and got them to sign over settlements for a song, then hid both the details of the transactions and their own business relationships from the courts.</p>

<p>Excuse me, Keith, are you using that Worst Person in the World Award? I think I found a winner.</p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=NZxrDfeo6kA:WUxqLHtQEnE:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/NZxrDfeo6kA" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Mark Sumner)</author>

<item>
<title>Donald Trump now says his infamous call to block Muslims from entering U.S. was 'only a suggestion'</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/qbH2w_VUMNw/-Donald-Trump-now-says-his-infamous-call-to-block-Muslims-from-entering-U-S-was-only-a-suggestion</link>
<description><p>It seems a little early for Donald Trump to start pivoting to "general election" mode, but apparently somebody's gotten through to him that he needs to turn the knob down a little if he intends to sell himself to people who do <em>not</em> base their lives around obsessive hatred of immigrants and Muslims. So it's <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/12/politics/donald-trump-muslim-ban/" title="">switcheroo time!</a></p>

<blockquote>Donald Trump, who issued a December press release "calling for a total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States," said Wednesday such a ban "hasn't been called for yet" and it was "only a suggestion."</blockquote>

<p>Yes, while his previous statements were very clear about "calling for" the complete ban, now he says it was just a suggestion and that he wasn't "calling for" it at all. That is the way Donald rolls. Donald does not constrain himself to the plane of reality that you and I inhabit, but switches between them at will.</p>

<p>Which is especially surprising because as of this very Monday, it wasn't a suggestion at all. He was asked about his ban and how it would relate to the newly elected—and Muslim—mayor of London, Sadiq Khan: Trump merely averred that "<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/politics/first-draft/2016/05/09/donald-trump-says-new-london-mayor-could-be-exception-to-his-ban-on-muslims/?_r=0">there will always be exceptions</a>" to his ban. And just as Trump was cooking his latest waffle, the fabulously wealthy T. Boone Pickens, a new Trump backer, was defending Trump's Muslim ban <a href="http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-05-11/oil-tycoon-pickens-backs-trump-call-for-temporary-ban-on-muslims">to reporters</a>.</p>

<blockquote>"Cut them off so we can figure out who they are coming in," Pickens told reporters at the conference.</blockquote>

<p>It's all right to throw your own supporters under your golden bus, Donald, but I don't know that you should be making T. Boone Pickens look like a chump.</p>

<p>Any wagers on how long it'll take Donald Trump to re-switch his position? Softening his grossly repulsive rhetoric against all Muslims, anywhere, probably won't sit well with his base, but then again his base probably knows by now not to put too much faith in anything Donald Trump says during any given interview.</p>

<p>Now if he says he's no longer committed to deporting 11 million people, that will be news.</p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=qbH2w_VUMNw:X7P3JHZz9lM:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/qbH2w_VUMNw" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Hunter)</author>

<title>Midday open thread: Remains of slaves to be reburied; bureaucracy drags feet in drug-war clemency</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/6A2aqTOxC8E/-Midday-open-thread-Remains-of-slaves-to-be-reburied-bureaucracy-drags-feet-in-drug-war-clemency</link>
<description><p>Today’s <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/blog/Comics" target="_blank">comic </a>by Ruben Bolling is <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/stories/2016/5/12/1525266/-Cartoon-The-Trump-Monster-returns-to-the-laboratory" target="_blank">The Trump Monster returns to the laboratory</a>:</p>

<div class="align-center">
<figure class="image-captioned"><img alt="Cartoon by Ruben Bolling -- The Trump monster returns to the laboratory " src="http://images.dailykos.com/images/250385/large/1287ckTEASER-republican-monster-experiments.png?1463021067" title="Cartoon by Ruben Bolling -- The Trump monster returns to the laboratory ">
<figcaption></figcaption>
</figure>
</div>

<p><strong>• </strong><a href="http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/latest-us-court-heard-appeal-abu-ghraib-torture-39065936" target="_blank">Judges hear appeal in Abu Ghraib torture case:</a><strong> </strong>Four Iraqis who say they were tortured at the notorious Abu Ghraib prison asked a three-judge panel of the 4th Circuit Court of Appeals Thursday to reinstate their lawsuit against a military contractor.<strong> </strong>They sued CACI Premier Technology Inc. in 2008, the contractor that conducted interrogations at the U.S.-run prison in Iraq. They claim CACI employees conspired to have soldiers shock, beat and sexually assault them to soften them up for questioning. A<span> judge tossed the case out last June on the grounds the military controlled the private contrators and he had no authority to question military judgment in the matter. The panel could take weeks to render a decision.</span></p>

<p><strong><span>• </span></strong><span><a href="http://bigstory.ap.org/article/75f14240af1b4c7f9be4e8702e85cc8e/ex-coal-ceo-blankenship-due-report-serve-sentence" target="_blank">Federal court says no to ex-coal CEO’s bid to remain free as he appeals his case.</a> Former Massey Energy CEO Don Blankenship was scheduled to report to an unnamed California prison Thursday to begin serving a one-year term for his conviction related to the deadliest mine disaster in 40 years. An explosion in the Massey-owned West Virginia Upper Big Branch coal mine killed 29 men in 2010. He has been free on a $1 million bond. Federal law allows convicted criminals to delay serving their sentences only under “exceptional circumstances.” They can stay out of prison pending appeal if there is a substantial question of law or fact that is likely to result in a reversal of the trial court’s verdict, unlikely in Blankenship’s case. </span></p>

<p><strong><span>•</span></strong><a href="http://bigstory.ap.org/article/78328c5aba3046beaf7d8c2121487a98/honor-last-former-slaves-reburied-centuries-later" target="_blank" title=""> Remains of slaves found in unmarked gravesite in New York will be reburied with ceremony</a><span>: The 14 bodies—of seven adults, five children and two infants—were found in 2005 when construction workers uncovered them. They will be memorialized in a public ceremony and reburied beside prominent families in old Albany.</span><strong><span> </span></strong><span>"It's something we agonize over because it's very rare that you have an opportunity to not just speak about the lives of the enslaved, but to actually do something to honor them," said Cordell Reaves, of the Schuyler Flatts Burial Ground Project. "We have an obligation to make sure that these people receive a level of dignity and respect that they never received in life."</span></p>

<p><strong>•</strong><span> <a href="http://www.timesdaily.com/news/nation/rocky-mountain-states-prepare-for-return-of-grizzly-hunts/article_953697ba-3f7c-5359-b723-f79ccf44d57e.html" target="_blank">Hunting of Yellowstone grizzlies depends on state plans in Idaho, Wyoming and Montana</a>: In March, the Obama administration proposed lifting the 41-year-old protections of the 700 grizzlies around Yellowstone National Park. Wildlife officials say the species has recovered enough that it can be hunted under strict controls. Grizzlies elsewhere in those states would remain protected. Officials hope to make a decision on based on the state management plans by March 2017. But wildlife advocates say the recovery of the grizzly population around Yellowstone is still too tenuous for hunting to be reinstated. Defenders of Wildlife say state plans should be fully vetted first. "All the work of bringing back the grizzly bear from the brink of extinction should not go up in smoke because the game plan is substandard," said Jamie Rappaport Clark, the organization's president and CEO, and a former director of the fish and wildlife service.</span></p>

<p><span><strong>•</strong> <a href="http://www.alternet.org/drugs/obama-effort-free-drug-war-prisoners-bureaucratic-roadblocks" target="_blank">Freedom for thousands of drug-war prisoners are being held up by </a>lack of resources: The Obama administration has commuted the sentences of 306 federal prisoners held for non-violent drug crimes. But the fate of thousands more are at risk because enough resources haven’t been committed to handle the deluge of applications that were submitted after the Justice Department announced that clemency would be granted to offenders who had served at least 10 years of their sentences, had good prison conduct, were unconnected to gangs or drug cartels and would probably receive a much lower sentence if they were convicted under today’s law, which has reduced the disparity in drug sentencing. Some 36,000 prisoners applied for clemency. The DOJ found that 9,500 met the criteria. But not enough people were hired to examine the applications in detail. Thus, clemency for these thousands is in limbo. So infuriated about this was Office of Pardons attorney Deborah Leff that she resigned.</span></p>

<p><strong><span>• </span></strong><a href="http://www.alternet.org/drugs/obama-effort-free-drug-war-prisoners-bureaucratic-roadblocks" target="_blank">Watch this video of Samantha Bee getting Michelle Branch to sing goodbye song to Ted Cruz.</a></p>

<p><strong>•</strong><a href="http://foreignpolicy.com/2016/05/11/dating-site-wants-to-help-americans-flee-trump-by-meeting-canadians/" target="_blank"> Canadian dating website offers hope in case of Trump presidency: </a><span>Joe Goldman, 25, says his new dating site,</span><span> </span><a href="http://www.maplematch.com/" target="_blank"><span>Maple Match</span></a><span>, “makes it easy for Americans to find the ideal Canadian partner to save them from the unfathomable horror of a Trump presidency.”</span></p>

<p><strong><span>• </span></strong><span><a href="https://www.dol.gov/sites/default/files/documents/newsroom/releases/eta/20160954.pdf" target="_blank">Applications for initial unemployment compensation rise to 15-month high</a>. The Department of Labor reported Thursday that first-time claims for jobless compensation rose to 294,000 last week. That is the highest level since February 2015. Initial claims have remained below 300,000 for</span> 62 consecutive weeks, the longest streak since 1973. For the week of April 16 this year, they reached the lowest point in more than four decades: 248,000. The four-week running average, which flattens the volatility of the weekly figures and gives a better overall picture of the situation, rose to 268,250 last week.</p>

<p><strong><span>• </span></strong>On <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/stories/2016/5/12/1525828/-Daily-Kos-Radio-s-KITM-podcast-AUDIO-Kagro-in-the-Morning-Thursday-May-12-2016" target="_blank">today’s <em>Kagro in the Morning</em> show</a>, <strong>Greg Dworkin</strong> sees something different about that Sanders WV win. Ryan &amp; von Clownstick’s historic Hairdo Summit. Will Sanders establish something anti-establishment, post-primaries? Electoral vote-splitting, unicameral legislature-having NE throws us yet another procedural curve.</p>

<item>
<title>House Republicans get a win on latest bogus Obamacare lawsuit</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/6rISKVAkCKE/-House-Republicans-get-a-win-on-latest-bogus-Obamacare-lawsuit</link>
<description><p>A federal judge <a href="http://www.cnbc.com/2016/05/12/judge-sides-with-house-republicans-against-obamacare.html">has ruled</a> (in what was a purely political dispute between House Republicans and the White House) that the Obama administration is unconstitutionally spending federal money to fund the president's health care law.</p>

<blockquote>At stake is $175 billion the government is paying to reimburse health insurers over a decade to reduce co-payments for lower-income people.
<p>The House argues that Congress never specifically appropriated that money and has denied an administration request for it, but that the administration is spending the money anyway.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>This is not a totally unexpected ruling, since the judge in question—U.S. District Judge Rosemary Collyer—was <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2015/5/29/1388786/-Republican-judge-ponders-impeachment-as-another-Obamacare-lawsuit-rears-its-ugly-nbsp-head">blatantly hostile</a> to the administration's arguments last year that the suit should be dismissed. The administration argued, with plenty of precedent behind it, that Congress did not have standing to sue on the issue, that the proper course for the alleged "harm" it was claiming was to fix it legislatively. Collyer, a 2002 Bush appointee, refused to dismiss the case despite precedent so it's not terribly surprising that she ruled for the House Republicans in the case.</p>

<p>The administration, which argued that there didn't need to be a separate appropriation for these funds because they were included in the general subsidies, will appeal. Collyer has stayed her order pending that appeal, so the subsidies will remain in place.</p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=6rISKVAkCKE:4cq6uaeh1yk:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/6rISKVAkCKE" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Joan McCarter)</author>

<item>
<title>Supreme Court vacancy watch Day 89: Pat Toomey's 'political stunt' fails</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/rmlMsiKZ3xk/-Supreme-Court-vacancy-watch-Day-89-Pat-Toomey-s-political-stunt-fails</link>
<description><p>It's Thursday, May 12 and Day 89 since Justice Antonin Scalia died and Mitch McConnell laid down his Supreme Court blockade: No meetings, no hearings, no votes on his replacement. It's also Day 57 since President Obama named Merrick Garland to be Scalia's replacement. What's the Senate doing today instead of considering the Supreme Court nominee? </p>

<p>Maybe, just maybe <a href="http://www.senate.gov/index.htm" title="">confirming a judge</a>. Paula Xinis has been waiting for a floor vote to fill the vacancy on the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland, Southern Division since <a href="https://www.mikulski.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/mikulski-cardin-praise-judiciary-committees-approval-of-nominee-paula-xinis-for-maryland-district-court-seat" title="">September 17, 2015</a>, when the Judiciary Committee approved her. She's the first of 11 federal district judges who have been passed out of committee and have yet to be voted on.</p>

<p>That she's getting this vote could actually kind of be attributed to a Republican, Sen. Pat Toomey from Pennsylvania. Toomey is facing a tough reelection and seems to think that Pennsylvania voters will ignore the fact that he's <a href="http://www.pennlive.com/opinion/2016/04/heres_why_im_opposing_merrick.html" title="">happily blockading</a> the Supreme Court nomination of Garland if he tries to get Pennsylvania judges confirmed. So on Wednesday, he <a href="http://www.post-gazette.com/news/state/2016/05/12/Toomey-presses-to-get-Pa-judicial-nominees-fast-tracked-for-vote/stories/201605120118" title="">tried to jump the queue</a> and get two of his nominees fast-tracked. The normal process for for nominees is 1) to actually get a vote on the floor, and 2) to be voted on in the order in which they were confirmed by the committee. Toomey's two judges are numbers nine and 10. His colleague, Democrat Bob Casey, had been on the floor Tuesday, attempting to get unanimous consent for all 11 of the district judges approved. </p>

<blockquote>Glenn Sugameli, a lawyer and activist who tracks court vacancies, said Mr. Toomey is cherry-picking nominees even though he knows the full Senate would never agree to take them up out of order.
<p>“It’s a political stunt that certainly appears to be for optics,” Mr. Sugameli said. “Objectively, he must have known that this would not work. If he had been serious he could have joined Sen. Casey on the floor the day before.”</p>
</blockquote>

<p>McConnell ultimately shot Toomey down, as he shot down Casey on Tuesday. But the fight did seem to shake loose the Xinis nomination. So there's that. No movement on the Supreme Court, where Toomey argues the vacancy has to be maintained because, according to spokesperson E.R. Anderson, "the long-term ideological balance of the nation's highest court is at stake with the Garland nomination, and we have an election right around the corner." It's been right around the corner for the past 89 days. From this whole kerfuffle you can conclude one thing: Pat Toomey is as full of shit as his fellow Republicans.</p>

<p><a href="https://secure.actblue.com/contribute/page/upgradethesenate2016?refcode=20160512JM1?tandembox=show" title="">Please donate $3 today to help turn the Senate blue. The future of the Supreme Court depends on it.</a></p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=rmlMsiKZ3xk:fe7UY5ju1TM:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/rmlMsiKZ3xk" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Joan McCarter)</author>
<category>MerrickGarland</category>
<category>MitchMcConnell</category>
<category>PatToomey</category>
<category>SCOTUS</category>

<pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 16:01:56 +0000</pubDate>
<feedburner:origLink>http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/05/12/1525831/-Supreme-Court-vacancy-watch-Day-89-Pat-Toomey-s-political-stunt-fails</feedburner:origLink></item>
<item>
<title>Yet another GOP plan to thwart Trump: Voters like swarms of things, right?</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/IunJhtgVocs/-Yet-another-GOP-plan-to-thwart-Trump-Voters-like-swarms-of-things-right</link>
<description><p>This is really going to happen, swear the few remaining Republicans clinging to a few last scraps of dignity. We're going to sabotage the takeover of the Republican Party by Birther Von Clownstick <a href="http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2016/05/never-trump-liz-mair-independent-candidate">even if it costs us any hope of the presidency</a>.</p>

<blockquote>Republican strategist Liz Mair, who has become one of the public faces of the anti-Trump crowd, tells Mother Jones that she's been having conversations with other leading conservatives opposed to Trump about a variety of backup options since Trump's last remaining rivals, Ted Cruz and John Kasich, dropped out of the race last week. One option, should they fail to recruit a viable candidate to run nationwide, is to get conservative candidates to run independent, single-state bids in as many states as possible.</blockquote>

<p>So option one is to find a magical rainbow-spitting unicorn and put him up as a third party candidate, but if that unicorn can't be found or would rather spend more time spitting rainbows with his own family then they'll recruit 50, or maybe 20 or 10, regular non-magical cocker spaniels and run them for president in their various individual home states. They won't win, mind you, but the theory is that it might at least be able to get depressed "real" Republicans to still come to the polls on election day. Ignore Donald Trump, you sad sacks: If you come out to vote, we'll at least let you pet this dog!</p>

<blockquote>A popular name at the top of the ballot in certain states could give anti-Trump Republicans who were thinking of sitting out the election a reason to go to the polls and vote for other Republicans on the ballot. "The main logic behind that, from what I can glean," Mair says, "is that people are really worried about down-ballot in that situation."</blockquote>

<p>Much of the rest of the article is devoted to the insistence that this could really happen and would really work, so let me just interject here with my regular reminder that this could Not really happen and would Not really work, because it is based on the presumption that there is a non-microscopic percentage of the Republican Party that still has either dignity or a few ideals of their own, and we've seen absolutely no evidence during the entire Obama presidency that such a thing exists, or that the party has any ideology whatsoever than despising the sitting president and/or the very notion of a government in general. The far more likely outcome is the one we're seeing play out: Donald Trump captures the nomination, and the Republican Party slides in behind him a la Chris Christie, pretending they were there all along. Build that wall! Deport everybody! And can we get some gold leaf on the Statue of Liberty over here? Show a little class, America.</p>

<p>By the convention they'll be singing Donald's praises like there was never any doubt in their minds. By October, Bill Kristol will have stapled a Trump campaign hat directly to his cranium.</p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=IunJhtgVocs:a4IcDpByr1I:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/IunJhtgVocs" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>

<item>
<title>North Carolina GOP to lobbyists: STFU on HB2 ... or else!</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/i3uJaWzg3HI/-North-Carolina-GOP-to-lobbyists-STFU-on-HB2-or-else</link>
<description><p><span>North Carolina Republicans are a little touchy these days after they enacted a blatantly discriminatory statute that is being likened to Jim Crow-era laws. But rather than resolving to repeal the bill, they’ve decided to bully state businesses instead. If everyone would just SHUT UP! about their disastrous legislating, everything would be fixed: that DOJ lawsuit, the thousands of lost jobs and millions in lost revenue, and a potential loss of <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/us-northcarolina-lgbt-legal-idUSKCN0Y12OG" target="_blank" title="">$4.8 billion in federal funding</a>—all just wiped away. Caitlin MacNeal <a href="http://talkingpointsmemo.com/livewire/lobbyists-pressure-hb2-north-carolina?utm_content=buffer6bfee&amp;utm_medium=social&amp;utm_source=twitter.com&amp;utm_campaign=buffer" target="_blank" title="">reports</a>:</span></p>

<blockquote>
<p><span>North Carolina Republican lawmakers have been threatening lobbyists with retribution if the businesses they represent speak out against the state's new controversial anti-LGBT law, according to a report from Raleigh television station <a href="http://www.wral.com/lobbyists-lawmakers-seek-to-quiet-hb2-opponents/15698344/"><span>WRAL</span></a>.</span></p>

<p><span>WRAL interviewed 11 lobbyists who said they have been warned by lawmakers or staff members about the potential for legislation targeting their clients or attempts to block legislation that lobbyists have been pushing. None of the lobbyists spoke on the record.</span></p>

<p><span>"I've never seen anything like it," one unnamed lobbyist told WRAL about the pressure seen from lawmakers.</span></p>
</blockquote>

<p><span>Republican Senate President Pro Tem Phil Berger was shocked by the revelation and said he had never heard of such a thing. But when the North Carolina Chamber of Commerce—which is supposed to be about promoting business in the state—issued a <a href="http://www.twcnews.com/nc/triangle-sandhills/news/2016/05/11/north-carolina-chamber-of-commerce-speaks-out-about-house-bill-2.html" target="_blank" title="">wishy-washy statement</a> on HB2 Wednesday after months of silence and failed to call for full repeal of the law, House Speaker Tim Moore was all too quick to praise the Chamber.</span></p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=i3uJaWzg3HI:T-mXIkaeYn8:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/i3uJaWzg3HI" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>

<item>
<title>A Trump victory was easy to foretell, unless you were an idiot</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/Ox9ayyVdekg/-A-Trump-victory-was-easy-to-foretell-unless-you-were-an-idiot</link>
<description><p>So there’s this thing in American punditry, where the conventional wisdom is eternally wrong, and when they’re proven wrong yet again, they look around and say <em>no one could’ve predicted</em> when in fact, lots of people had predicted. Jonathan Chait, for one, has gotten <a href="http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2016/05/heres-the-real-reason-we-all-underrated-trump.html" target="_blank">really good at that</a>. </p>

<blockquote>
<p><strong>Here’s the Real Reason Everybody Thought Trump Would Lose</strong></p>
</blockquote>

<p>Atrios <a href="http://www.eschatonblog.com/2016/05/think-pieces-about-meeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee.html" target="_blank">responds</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
<p><span>I'm tired of reading think pieces about WHY WE ALL THOUGHT DONALD TRUMP WOULD LOSE (I'm looking at you, Chait). First of all, we all didn't, you and your circle jerk did. Secondly, I don't care what your prior beliefs about the Republican party were. If you were an alien anthropologist sent to study this election but otherwise didn't know a damn thing about about the American electorate, you would have looked at the polls and predicted a Trump win. Thirdly, to the extent that your knowledge of Republican voters might have added a bit of special sauce to your poll analysis, we hippie liberals have been telling you for years that a sizeable chunk of Republican voters are absolute blithering idiots. Also, racist. This is not news.</span></p>
</blockquote><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=Ox9ayyVdekg:QvKZjLdLmJE:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/Ox9ayyVdekg" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>

<item>
<title>Paul Ryan and Donald Trump talk the talk about unity, but Ryan still doesn't endorse Trump</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/24Y_r2g29sQ/-Paul-Ryan-and-Donald-Trump-talk-the-talk-about-unity-but-Ryan-still-doesn-t-endorse-Trump</link>
<description><p>Donald Trump and House Speaker Paul Ryan had their big meeting Thursday morning (along with Republican National Committee Chair Reince Priebus and other Republican leaders), and it came out seeming … not so big after all. But! After a meeting that was briefer than its advance publicity suggested, Trump and Ryan issued a “<a href="https://twitter.com/jamiedupree/status/730776397963243520" target="_blank" title="">joint statement</a>.”</p>

<blockquote>
<p>The United States cannot afford another four years of the Obama White House, which is what Hillary Clinton represents. That is why it’s critical that Republicans unite around our shared principles, advance a conservative agenda, and do all we can to win this fall. With that focus, we had a great conversation this morning. While we were honest about our few differences, we recognize that there are also many important areas of common ground. We will be having additional discussions, but remain confident there’s a great opportunity to unify our party and win this fall, and we are totally committed to working together to achieve that goal. We are extremely proud of the fact that many millions of new voters have entered the primary system, far more than ever before in the Republican Party’s history. This was our first meeting, but it was a very positive step toward unification.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>So … Ryan’s staff wrote that up in advance, right? Because there is precious little Trump voice in there. For one thing, who believes that Trump is planning to take steps toward unification? No, that’s going to be all on Ryan, and both men know it. So all the talk about unifying is really talk about how much Ryan will allow himself to be absorbed into the Trump borg. Answer: still no real endorsement, but he knows it’s going to happen. Even this mealy-mouthed statement and whatever private discussion was behind it was good enough for Priebus, though:</p>

<div class="dk-editor-embed center-block" data-twitter-content='&amp;lt;blockquote class="twitter-tweet"&amp;gt;&amp;lt;p lang="en" dir="ltr"&amp;gt;The meeting was great.  It was a very positive step toward party unity.&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;&amp;amp;mdash; Reince Priebus (@Reince) &amp;lt;a href="https://twitter.com/Reince/status/730762270150696960"&amp;gt;May 12, 2016&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/blockquote&amp;gt;
'>
<div class="remove-embed-content">x</div>
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet">
<p lang="en" dir="ltr">The meeting was great.  It was a very positive step toward party unity.</p>— Reince Priebus (@Reince) <a href="https://twitter.com/Reince/status/730762270150696960">May 12, 2016</a>
</blockquote>
</div>

<p> Great! Positive! I swear! My enthusiasm is not at all forced!</p>

<p>Sure, guys.</p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=24Y_r2g29sQ:p5odkUdg5aI:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/24Y_r2g29sQ" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Laura Clawson)</author>

<item>
<title>Illinois Sen. Mark Kirk attacks challenger Tammy Duckworth's service to veterans</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/c7yZtY6Ib-s/-Mark-Kirk-attacks-Tammy-Duckworth-s-service-to-veterans</link>
<description><figure class="image-captioned width-sm"><a href="https://secure.actblue.com/contribute/page/dkfortd?refcode=20160512JM1thermometer?tandembox=show"><img alt="Goal Thermometer" src="https://secure.actblue.com/x/object/actblue-badges/page/dkfortd/thermometer/dark.png"></a>

<figcaption></figcaption>
</figure>

<p>Republican Illinois Sen. Mark Kirk is more than willing to play dirty to keep his very endangered Senate seat against his Democratic challenger, Rep. Tammy Duckworth. That means going after the Iraq war hero, who lost both her legs, for <a href="http://www.nwherald.com/2016/05/11/u-s-sen-mark-kirk-targeting-tammy-duckworths-record-on-veterans/aam8zqi/?page=1">her work in the Illinois and U.S. Veterans Affairs departments</a>. He launched an online ad this week featuring a discrimination lawsuit brought by two Illinois VA employees against Duckworth—a suit that's already been dismissed, twice. It's a controversial move, even among his own supporters.</p>

<blockquote>Garrett Anderson, who lost part of one arm and suffered traumatic brain injury in a roadside-bomb attack in Iraq, said Duckworth was the first service member the U.S. Army sniper spoke to when he woke up from a coma at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in 2005.
<p>The 39-year-old University of Illinois graduate student plans to vote for Kirk this fall for a simple reason: Anderson is a Republican. But he said the ads targeting her are out of bounds and called Duckworth "a nice person" who has a strong track record of looking out for veterans.</p>

<p>"I've seen a few of (the ads) and I don't like them because she served her country very well, and she's a decorated war veteran," Anderson said. […]</p>

<p>[Duckworth's] Deputy campaign manager Matt McGrath called it "a cynical and desperate ploy." He said Duckworth gets most of her own health care at Hines [VA medical center] and is "deeply familiar" with issues at VA medical centers.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Kirk is desperate, and is going after Duckworth on her biggest strength: Her service in the military and after the war, her service to veterans. It's not going over well with veterans or the political action committee VoteVets, which promises "to  spend significant money to attack Kirk."  He'll richly deserve every dollar spent against him.</p>

<p><a href="https://secure.actblue.com/contribute/page/dkfortd?refcode=20160512JM1&amp;tandembox=show" title="">Please donate $3 to help Tammy Duckworth turn the Senate blue.</a></p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=c7yZtY6Ib-s:PyIJskDFXKA:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/c7yZtY6Ib-s" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>

<item>
<title>Trump won't release his tax returns to voters. But to get a casino license ...</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/5s99kEJ5ipo/-Trump-won-t-release-his-tax-returns-to-voters-State-gambling-officials-are-another-story</link>
<description><p>Donald Trump’s <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/stories/2016/5/11/1525383/-Trump-refuses-to-release-tax-returns" target="_blank">claim</a> that “there’s nothing to learn” from his tax returns is ludicrous on its face. Here’s a guy running for president basically on the claim that he’s the richest and the savviest businessman ever to make a deal, and voters wouldn’t learn anything from his tax returns? Snort.</p>

<p>As the <em>Washington Post</em>’s fact checker points out, <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2016/05/12/trumps-false-claim-that-theres-nothing-to-learn-from-his-tax-returns/" target="_blank">we’d learn</a> how much money Trump actually makes (as opposed to his likely inflated claims), where his income comes from, how much he gives to charity, and how aggressively he games the tax system to his benefit. We’d also learn a little something about Trump’s willingness to live up to his years of promises that he’d totally be happy to release his tax returns eventually at some future point. </p>

<p>But while Trump says he won’t release his tax returns to mere voters—something every presidential candidate for 40 years has done—that <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/11/politics/donald-trump-casino-licenses-tax-returns/index.html" target="_blank">doesn’t mean he’s never released them</a> to anyone.</p>

<blockquote>
<div>Trump has handed over tax returns in the midst of audits before -- to state gambling officials in Pennsylvania and New Jersey, as part of the process of seeking casino licenses in those states.</div>
</blockquote>

<p>That’s right. Donald Trump will release his tax returns to get a casino license, but not to be elected president.</p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=5s99kEJ5ipo:i43wLW2JWVM:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/5s99kEJ5ipo" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
