<item>
<title>Morning Digest: Quinnipiac finds McGinty surging into a post-primary tossup with Toomey</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/-EaxFNl0TZQ/-Morning-Digest-Quinnipiac-finds-McGinty-surging-into-a-post-primary-tossup-with-Toomey</link>
<description><p><strong>Leading Off</strong>:</p>

<p><a href="#1" name="1">●</a> <strong>FL-Sen, OH-Sen, PA-Sen</strong>: So <a href="https://www.qu.edu/news-and-events/quinnipiac-university-poll/2016-presidential-swing-state-polls/release-detail?ReleaseID=2345">those new swing state polls</a> from Quinnipiac that had people worked up over how close they showed Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump actually contain … <a href="https://www.qu.edu/news-and-events/quinnipiac-university-poll/2016-presidential-swing-state-polls/release-detail?ReleaseID=2346">good news for Democratic Senate candidates</a>? So they do. In Ohio, Quinnipiac finds Democratic ex-Gov. Ted Strickland edging GOP Sen. Rob Portman 43-42, essentially unchanged from Strickland's 44-42 lead in February. Meanwhile, in Pennsylvania, Democrat Katie McGinty has seen a considerable post-nomination bounce and now trails GOP Sen. Pat Toomey 45-44, much tighter than the 47-38 advantage Toomey had a month ago.</p>

<p>Florida's always more complicated, because the Sunshine State doesn't hold its primary until August, and Quinnipiac matched all five Republicans against both of the Democrats running, Reps. Patrick Murphy and Alan Grayson. Murphy performs better, leading all five matchups by anywhere from 36-35 (against Rep. Ron DeSantis) to 38-32 (versus wealthy businessman Carlos Beruff). Grayson also does best against Beruff but only leads by 1 point, 36-35. He ties Lt. Gov. Carlos Lopez-Cantera at 37 apiece and trails the other three Republicans (DeSantis, Rep. David Jolly, and businessman Todd Wilcox) by 2 points in each case.</p>

<p>In any event, if you believe that Quinnipiac's samples were too bearish for Clinton, then they'd be underestimating Democrats' chance in these three Senate races, too. But even if you think these polls are spot-on, Democrats ought to be quite pleased to see all these tossups, especially in the case of McGinty, who has evidently caught up quite a bit.</p>

<p>However, there's still an issue of concern: Quinnipiac's surveys were in the field for an inordinate length of time, from April 27 to May 8. A normal poll is conducted over three nights; this one took 12 days. And something rather momentous took place in that timeframe, namely, the fact that Trump became the presumptive GOP nominee (and the media finally—mostly—started treating Clinton as the winner, too). You never know how a long field period will affect a poll, but that's precisely why you try to keep them short in the first place. This is a very good reason to wait and see what other polls have to say before coming to any conclusions.</p><div class="feedflare">

<title>George Zimmerman announces plan to auction the gun he used to kill Trayvon Martin</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/Y0bJ9qxrc28/-George-Zimmerman-announces-plan-to-auction-the-gun-he-used-to-kill-Trayvon-Martin</link>
<description><p>George Zimmerman, the self-appointed neighborhood watchman who killed Trayvon Martin in 2013, continues to find new ways to maintain his title as the worst person in the U.S. This time, he’s selling the gun he used to kill Trayvon Martin. From <a href="http://www.fox35orlando.com/news/local-news/140127772-story" target="_blank">Fox 35:</a></p>

<blockquote>
<p>The 9mm pistol that Zimmerman said was used to shoot and kill Trayvon Martin on February 26, 2012 is up for sale in an online auction.   FOX 35 spoke to Zimmerman about the weapon and its sale.  "I recently received it back from the Department of Justice. They took it after my trial, after I was exonerated," he said. </p>

<p>We reached out to Trayvon Martin's family attorney for comment. While they didn't want to talk about Zimmerman, they gave us a statement which reads, "The Trayvon Martin Foundation is committed to its mission of ending senseless gun violence in the United States.  This election season, we are laser focused on furthering that mission. As such, the foundation has no comment on the actions of that person."</p>
</blockquote>

<p>What does he plan to do with the money? Fight Hillary Clinton, who will appear at a fundraiser for the <a href="http://www.capitalnewyork.com/article/florida/2016/05/8598975/zimmerman-auction-gun-killed-trayvon-martin-might-use-cash-against-c" target="_blank">Trayvon Martin Foundation later this month:</a></p>

<blockquote>
<p>But Zimmerman told Fox 35 that “legally, nothing stopped me nor stops me currently from owning or possessing a fire arm.” Fox 35 reporter <a href="https://twitter.com/vboey/status/730585350922489856">Valerie Boey said on Twitter </a>that he told her he would “use the proceeds to fight against Hillary Clinton and State Attorney Angela Corey,” who prosecuted him unsuccessfully in 2013</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Last year he sold <a href="http://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-33979927" target="_blank" title="">Confederate flag-themed paintings</a> and split the proceeds with a gun store owner in Florida who declared his store a “Muslim-free zone.” </p>

      </div>

Sanders backers would vote Trump</a>. <title>Cheers and Jeers: Thursday</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/-2XoDop_z5Y/-Cheers-and-Jeers-Thursday</link>
<description><p>From the GREAT STATE OF MAINE…</p>

<p><strong>Netroots Nation 2016: 9 Weeks and Counting</strong></p>

<p>63 days 'til the <a href="http://www.netrootsnation.org/" target="_blank" title=""><strong>July 14-17 convention</strong></a> in St. Louis, and the big story this week is the official announcement of the panels that were selected. Over to you, Raven Brooks:</p>

<blockquote>
<p>After almost two months of reading and scoring hundreds of panel submissions, we're proud to announce the ones chosen to be presented at Netroots Nation this summer---and <strong>the most diverse group of speakers in our 11-year history.</strong></p>

<figure class="image-captioned width-md align-right"><img alt="Netroots Nation 2016 logo.  St. Louis" src="http://images.dailykos.com/images/162676/large/Netroots_Nation_2016.png?1453749144" title="Netroots Nation 2016 logo.  St. Louis">
<figcaption></figcaption>
</figure>

<p>Racial justice is front and center in our agenda this year. You’ll find sessions calling out the policies that cemented the racism that’s still prevalent today, as well as panels that highlight the powerful organizing being done around the country in the movement for Black lives.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Among the panels that were chosen:</p>

<blockquote>
<ul>
	<li>Black Voices, Black Victories: Changing the Story on Race in a Digital Age</li>
	<li>
	<p>The Racist Policies that Built Ferguson (and Baltimore and Flint)</p>
	</li>
	<li>Justice at the Ballot Box: How Holding Prosecutors Accountable in Elections is Key to Criminal Justice Reform</li>
	<li>Authentically Engaging with Trans Leadership in Progressive Organizing</li>
	<li>How to Have a Conversation About Race Without Everyone Running Out of the Room</li>
	<li>Rejecting the Pale, Male and Stale Leadership Pipeline: A Roadmap to Building Inclusive Organizations</li>
	<li>From Ferguson to Flint: Building Black Political Power in Flyover Country</li>
</ul>
</blockquote>

<p>Raven says there are also panels "covering the future of the Supreme Court and next steps for the LGBTQ movement, as well as sessions expanding and challenging the media narrative around issues like abortion and paid family and medical leave."</p>

<p><strong>Two impressive statistics</strong> that demonstrate how the convention is working hard to be more diverse: 65 percent of the speakers and moderators are people of color, and 65 percent are women.</p>

<p>You can <strong><a href="http://www.netrootsnation.org/our-nn16-agenda/" target="_blank" title="">check out the complete Netroots Nation agenda by clicking here</a></strong>. Once again, my <em>Anarchy 101</em> seminar was rejected because my proposal was too disorganized. Well…poo.</p>

<figure class="image-captioned width-md align-left"><img alt="mango_restaurant.jpg" src="http://images.dailykos.com/images/241887/large/mango_restaurant.jpg?1461196749" title="mango_restaurant.jpg">
<figcaption></figcaption>
</figure>

<p><span>►</span><span style="text-align:center"> </span>If you're planning to be in St. Louis the day before the convention, please join us at the annual <strong>Daily Kos/Connect-Unite-Act/C&amp;J Eat-'n-Greet</strong> at <strong><a href="http://www.mangoperu.com/" target="_blank" title="">Mango</a></strong> (right near the convention hall). To add your name to the list, <strong><a href="http://www.dailykos.com/newthread/navajo" target="_blank" title="">email Navajo</a></strong> and then circle Wednesday, July 13 on your calendar. No better way to get in the convention spirit and meet up with Kossacks from far and wide.</p>

<p><span>►</span> Sign up to be a volunteer. Email Eric at: <u>volunteers [at] netrootsnation.org</u>.</p>

<item>
<title>Abbreviated Pundit Round-up: Disaffection, not ideology, driving the votes</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/CeQ4ijRSPR8/-Abbreviated-Pundit-Round-up-Disaffection-not-ideology-driving-the-votes</link>
<description><p><a href="http://cookpolitical.com/story/9309" target="_blank">Marc Hetherington and Drew Englehart</a> from Feb, but still quite relevant:</p>

<blockquote>
<p>Those who provide the least resentful responses about blacks (“strongly agree” to questions 1 and 2; “strongly disagree” to questions 3 and 4) score at 0 and those who provide the most resentful responses to the four items (“strongly agree” to questions 3 and 4; “strongly disagree” to questions 1 and 2) score at 1. Of course, the average response for most people is somewhere in between.  In the chart below, we display the distributions of scores calculated from the survey responses. The higher the bar is, the more people fall into the category. Blue bars correspond to white Democrats and red bars correspond to white Republicans. The panel on the left is from responses in 1986, the first year the items were asked. The panel on the right is from responses in 2016, data that were released earlier this week. </p>
</blockquote>

<p><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/paloma/daily-202/2016/05/11/daily-202-west-virginia-results-show-disaffection-not-ideology-fuels-sanders-and-trump/57322d0b981b92a22d72af0d/" target="_blank">WaPo</a>: </p>

<blockquote>
<p>Americans, collectively, are not as angry as watching cable TV would lead you to believe. But many poorer, less-educated folks who have been left behind in the 21st century—the ones who have seen their wages stagnate, their opportunities for upward mobility disappear and their life expectancies shorten—are looking to disrupt a status quo that has not worked for them.</p>

<p>That’s what Sanders and Trump are both promising to do.</p>

<p>And that’s the main reason why Bernie beat Hillary Clinton in yesterday’s West Virginia Democratic primary by <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/2016-election-results/west-virginia">15.4 points</a>. He carried every single county in the Mountaineer State, which by every metric has been left behind. (Trump, the presumptive Republican nominee, won 77 percent of the vote in the uncontested GOP primary.)</p>

<p>Fewer than 1 in 5 Democratic primary voters in West Virginia identified as “very liberal,” tying Oklahoma for the lowest in any of this year’s contests. Yet Sanders carried both states. In fact, Sanders won among self-identified moderate-to-conservative Democrats in each.</p>

<p>So how did the septuagenarian socialist do it? The bottom line is most people are not voting for Bernie because he is liberal. They are voting for him because they perceive his promised “political revolution” as a challenge to the system that has failed them.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>This is an under-discussed topic here. Many Bernie voters here want to see a more progressive approach to foreign and domestic policy. That’s no surprise, Daily Kos being what it is.  But out there in the states, many Bernie voters want the opposite.</p>

<p>Sure, if it’s a voter for your candidate, you’ll take it (I will gladly accept Republican and conservative votes for Hillary in November. If you want to be a purist, vote Ron Paul.) But don’t be fooled by propaganda suggesting all or even most Bernie voters want what you want, or that people in West, by God, Virginia voted for Bernie because they want single payer.</p>

<p>Bernie didn’t win West, by God, Virginia or Oklahoma on the strength of a progressive vision of America. He won it, and OK and a few other states on the basis of a rejection of the status quo that cuts across ideological lines, similar to Donald Trump’s voters. And in places like West, by God, Virginia, there are other factors in play: coal, disaffected white resentment and a bit of misogyny thrown in. That doesn’t mean we at Daily Kos vote for Bernie for those reasons, but it is a part of the broader Bernie coalition (and is, alas, a part of any voter coalition, Hillary included).</p>

<p>It won’t be enough to win the primaries, which have been effectively over for a month. Just keep in mind a Bernie vote doesn’t always mean what you think it means or want it to mean. That’s why it’s not shocking at all in West, by God, Virginia, you see <a href="http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2016-election/sanders-wins-west-virginia-democratic-primary-n571356" target="_blank" title="">these results</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
<p><span>Exit polls Tuesday found only 33 percent of West Virginia Democrats are committed to voting Democrat in November. Around 27 percent of the state's Democrats said they would vote for Trump and 36 percent said it would depend.</span></p>
</blockquote>

<p>No, that doesn’t make Bernie a stronger candidate in November. No, it doesn’t mean Donald Trump will win (even if he wins OK and West, by God, Virginia). No, it doesn’t mean Bernie’s votes don’t count. No, it doesn’t mean that you should change your vote or that Bernie should get out of the race. But don’t read a Bernie win in a given state as a mandate for a progressive future, either. Some Bernie voters didn’t vote for that.</p>

<p>Take a look below at the <em>Scalawag Magazine</em> piece on WV.</p>

<p>And vote with your eyes open. It’s better that way.</p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=CeQ4ijRSPR8:o0K0L4ZQgk0:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/CeQ4ijRSPR8" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Greg Dworkin)</author>
<category>AbbreviatedPunditRound-up</category>

<item>
<title>Open thread for night owls: Google bans payday lenders from their ad network</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/t1URpZSeEps/-Open-thread-for-night-owls-Google-bans-payday-lenders-from-their-ad-network</link>
<description><figure class="image-captioned width-md align-right"><img alt="BladeRunnerOwlBadgeTEXT.jpg" src="http://images.dailykos.com/images/107254/large/BladeRunnerOwlBadgeTEXT.jpg?1453305834" title="BladeRunnerOwlBadgeTEXT.jpg">
<figcaption></figcaption>
</figure>

<p>Online advertising continues to be inundated with sketchy products. Our computer screens serve as unwilling hosts to ads for nutritional supplements of dubious nutrition, wacky health tips that will probably do nothing for your health, ads for reverse mortgages, and there's no better way to make even the most up-and-up product look cheap and crooked than to put it in Satan's own personal contribution to the effort, the animated gif. But Google today announced that it will be greatly restricting one particular product from their own ad networks as being conspicuously <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2016/05/google-payday-loan-ads/482340/">worse than even those</a>.</p>

<blockquote>On Wednesday, the search engine announced that it would ban ads for payday lenders (and similar services) starting on July 13.</blockquote>

<p>So-called "payday loans" will be defined by Google as loans repayable within 60 days or with APRs equal or greater than 36%. Predatory under almost any circumstances, the online variation can be even more dangerous for consumers than the strip mall version:</p>

<blockquote>A report from Upturn, a technology-focused consulting firm, outlines why the use of ad targeting for this specific product is particularly harmful. The report details how an action as simple as searching the term “need money to pay bills” can start a dangerous cycle, in which information about an individual’s location, bank accounts, income, and financial health can be collected by lead generators and then dispersed through a more opaque process that can result in fraud, targeted high-priced loans, and harassment from multiple high-cost lenders.</blockquote>

<p>It's not clear how much the new policy will help, or how vigilant the company will be in stripping offenders from their ad network after the July 13th deadline. Coupled with similar policies from Facebook, however, it should <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/05/11/google-to-ban-payday-loan-advertisements/" target="_blank" title="">at least throw a wrench in the lenders’ gears.</a></p>

<blockquote>Washington regulators, as well as a handful of states, have been trying to limit the activities of payday lenders by capping how much they can charge consumers in an interest rate. But the decisions by tech giants Facebook and Google – the two biggest websites on the planet – might have as much impact as any single regulation in restricting access to payday lenders.</blockquote>

<hr>
<p class="AlignCenter"><strong><a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/05/11/1525241/-High-Impact-Posts-May-10-2016" target="_blank">HIGH IMPACT STORIES</a> • <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/stories/2016/5/11/1525501/-Top-Comments-Open-Thread-Wednesday-Edition" target="_blank">TOP COMMENTS</a></strong></p>

</blockquote>

<p class="AlignCenter"><strong>BLAST FROM THE PAST</strong></p>

<p>At Daily Kos on this date in <strong>2008</strong>—<a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2008/05/11/513967/-Enter-the-Inhofian-Polar-Bear-Expert" target="_blank">Enter the Inhofian Polar Bear Expert</a>:</p>

<div class="table-wrapper">
<table cellpadding="5%" style="border:1px dashed black" width="96%">
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p><span>What a coincidence.</span></p>

			<p><span>Just as the Alaska State Legislature </span><a href="http://www.desmogblog.com/paying-for-the-science-they-want-alaska-state-legislators-go-denier-shopping">allocates $2 million</a><span> for a conference promoting climate change deniers' "expert" analysis of why polar bears aren't really endangered, a poster boy for polar bear junk science emerges from the woodwork.</span></p>

			<p>Enter <a href="http://jscottarmstrong.com/"><span>J. Scott Armstrong</span></a>, who is a marketing professor at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania. His research emphasizes forecasting methods, which he has used as the cornerstone for—you guessed it—<a href="http://www.realclimate.org/index.php/archives/2007/07/green-and-armstrongs-scientific-forecast/"><span>claims</span></a>  that the IPCC climate change projections are actually <em>all wrong</em>.</p>

			<p>Now he's extended his "forecasts" to say that polar bears are doing just fine. He alluded to his research when Sen. James Inhofe <a href="http://epw.senate.gov/public/index.cfm?FuseAction=Hearings.Statement&amp;Statement_ID=912e7f15-6092-4edc-aa65-2cac3db6870e"><span>called him</span></a>  as an "expert" to <a href="http://epw.senate.gov/public/index.cfm?FuseAction=Hearings.Testimony&amp;Hearing_ID=abffa4ef-802a-23ad-445f-e4d88bad74b1&amp;Witness_ID=eac910e4-dd22-406e-bf26-908d1694d086"><span>testify</span></a> before the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee regarding the proposed endangered status of the polar bear; now, Armstrong has released an official statement advertising his paper. […]</p>

			<p>Armstrong's claims regarding the increasing polar bear population have been debunked <a href="http://gristmill.grist.org/story/2007/9/10/10141/7952"><span>again</span></a> and <a href="http://climateprogress.org/2007/09/11/will-polar-bears-go-extinct-by-2030-part-ii/"><span>again</span></a>  (which doesn't stop <a href="http://thinkprogress.org/2008/04/04/beck-inhofe-bears/"><span>Inhofe and others</span></a>  from repeating the claims, of course).</p>
			</td>
		</tr>

<title>Michigan State Police being sued for retaliation after being sued for discrimination</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/7dR-vX6qg14/-Michigan-State-Police-being-sued-for-retaliation-after-being-sued-for-discrimination</link>
<description><p>An institution must protect itself if it is to remain true to its definition. What does that protection look like in a society that, according to the feminist theorist <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bell_hooks" target="_blank" title="">bell hooks</a>, is white supremacist hetero-patriarchal? Welp … enter the Michigan State Police (MSP), an entity that has “struggled” with “diversity” since <em>before</em> a consent decree reached with the federal government was lifted back in 1993. This week, two African-American members of the force spoke about their experiences with discrimination. The men, who have a total of 35 years on the job between them, are suing the state police. Why? They say it’s because they’ve been <a href="http://www.freep.com/story/news/local/michigan/2016/05/08/michigan-state-police-discrimination-lawsuits-diversity-police-troopers-darzeil-hall-lamarr-johnson/81485506" title="">retaliated against</a> … for suing the state police.</p>

<p>Darzeil Hall and Lamarr Johnson sued the MSP for racial discrimination and were awarded $5.2 million by a jury in 2013. Since then, the two say they’ve faced a variety of petty harassments (both professional and personal), unwarranted investigations, and denials of promotion.</p>

<blockquote>
<p>Hall says he didn’t suffer any major issues with racial discrimination through most of his 20-year career. But that began to change in December 2010, when he says that he and Johnson thought they had passed a training course for firearms examination. They were even given certificates at a public ceremony.”</p>

<p>“Two months later, they said, they were both removed from the program they thought they had passed, on accusations of poor performance. White participants who had lower scores were promoted, records have shown.</p>
</blockquote>

<p><span>The pair made the decision to sue, and say that’s when even more discrimination began happening.</span></p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=7dR-vX6qg14:iKLcmjhe3-c:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/7dR-vX6qg14" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Thandisizwe Chimurenga)</author>

<item>
<title>Donald Trump earns widespread support from Europe's far-right leaders</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/I5NtwLygGSA/-Donald-Trump-earns-widespread-support-from-Europe-s-far-right-leaders</link>
<description><p>Donald Trump’s presidential campaign platform of bigoted, anti-immigrant, Islamophobic right-wing populism hasn’t just been a smash success in the GOP primaries: It also has a wide swath of <a href="https://www.buzzfeed.com/sirajdatoo/far-right-in-europe-hope-donald-trump-will-set-them-free?utm_term=.opGVrVxwM#.emBolo4QZ" target="_blank" title="">admirers across the Atlantic</a>. Though Trump has provoked strong opposition from the political mainstream around the world, he has won the support of extremists who share his hostility to Muslims, immigration, cosmopolitan social values, the political establishment, and even the NATO military alliance.</p>

<p>Right-wing populism <a href="http://prospect.org/article/trumpism-transatlantic-phenomenon" target="_blank" title="">has surged</a> in the last several years in Europe, and in most countries it’s found a home in one or more political parties—many of them relatively new. These parties’ leaders appeal lies in their extreme nationalist sentiments and overt bigotry toward out groups. For instance, Dutch Freedom Party leader Geert Wilders wants to <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/18/dutch-far-right-leader-geert-wilders-goeson-trial-for-inciting-hatred" target="_blank" title="">end Muslim immigration</a> and has stated that if the Netherlands bans <em>Mein Kampf</em>, it should <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2015/05/04/geert-wilders-the-champion-of-free-speech-in-texas-wants-to-ban-the-koran-in-holland/" target="_blank" title="">ban the Quran</a> too. The Sweden Democrats have their <a href="http://foreignpolicy.com/2014/09/16/how-a-former-neo-nazi-party-became-swedens-third-largest/" target="_blank">roots in neo-Nazism</a>, and France’s National Front has long been the home of <a href="http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/1578053/Le-Pen-found-guilty-of-Holocaust-denial.html" target="_blank">Holocaust deniers and fascist sympathizers</a>.</p>

<p>In fact, Trump is now so popular among Europe's far-right leaders, we need a scorecard <a href="https://www.facebook.com/ianbremmer/posts/491380824368300" target="_blank">just to keep track of everyone who’s endorsed him</a>:  </p>

<div class="table-wrapper">
<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="dk5-table" width="192">
	<thead>
		<tr style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">
			<th style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">Country</th>
			<th style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">Leader</th>
			<th style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">Party</th>
		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">Belgium</td>
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">Tom Van Grieken</td>
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vlaams_Belang" title="">Flemish Interest (Vlaams Belang)</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">Czech Republic</td>
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">Miroslav Lidinský</td>
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawn_-_National_Coalition" title="">Dawn - National Coalition</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">France</td>
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">Jean-Marie Le Pen</td>
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Front_(France)">National Front</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">Italy</td>
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">Matteo Salvini</td>
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lega_Nord">Northern League (Lega Nord)</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">The Netherlands</td>
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">Geert Wilders</td>
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Party_for_Freedom">Party for Freedom</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">Serbia</td>
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">Vojislav Šešelj</td>
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbian_Radical_Party" title="">Serbian Radical Party</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">Sweden</td>
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">Jimmie Åkesson</td>
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sweden_Democrats">Sweden Democrats</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">The United Kingdom</td>
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)">Nigel Farage</td>
			<td style="color:rgb(60, 55, 54)"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UK_Independence_Party">UK Independence Party</a></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>
</div>

<p>Perhaps most seriously of all, Trump has the support of Russian leader<a href="https://www.buzzfeed.com/maxseddon/putin-endorses-donald-trump-for-president?utm_term=.if0gVgrKB#.wszxkxKp8" target="_blank"> Vladimir Putin</a>, who himself has <a href="http://www.politico.eu/article/le-pen-russia-crimea-putin-money-bank-national-front-seeks-russian-cash-for-election-fight/" target="_blank">financially supported</a> far-right European parties like the National Front.</p>

<p>As Trump might say, he has tremendous support from the classiest world leaders.</p><div class="feedflare">

<item>
<title>The Washington Post: Trump was only a misogynist back when he was a 'towel-snapping bro'</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/vUCVnHOq7Pk/-The-Washington-Post-Trump-was-only-a-misogynist-back-when-he-was-a-towel-snapping-bro</link>
<description><p>Women don’t like Donald Trump. In fact, <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/04/28/1521081/-Go-ahead-Donald-just-keep-talkin-about-how-much-the-ladies-dislike-Hillary" target="_blank">70 percent</a> of women have a negative view of the presumptive nominee of the Republican Party. But maybe those little ladies are just being hysterical (plus, you can’t discount the fact that they could have had <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2015/08/08/politics/donald-trump-cnn-megyn-kelly-comment/" target="_blank">"blood coming out" from "wherever"</a> when polled), so let’s calm down and let <em><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/from-playboy-to-president-trumps-past-behavior-collides-with-his-white-house-bid/2016/05/09/46bed6f8-12fe-11e6-93ae-50921721165d_story.html?postshare=7101462876830772&amp;tid=ss_tw" target="_blank">The Washington Post</a> </em>explain how Trump probably didn’t mean all the vile, misogynistic slurs he’s spewed over the years. </p>

<p><em>The Post </em>begins with a series of exchanges Trump had with shock-jock Howard Stern over a period of 15 years—including, shortly after the death of Princess Diana, when Trump agreed that he probably could have “nailed” her, not to mention confirming that he would “bang” Mariah Carey “without hesitation”—before explaining:</p>

<blockquote>
<p><span>Trump’s crude talk on-air with Stern … was part of an image he cultivated as a Manhattan playboy who had so many women that he barely had time to sleep … That reputation was useful as Trump, in his 40s and 50s, built a brand designed to equate his name with success and the high life. </span></p>
</blockquote>

<p>There, you see? It was all an act! To get attention! Of course <em>The Post</em> doesn’t explain how Trump’s comments to Stern during that same period, where he <a href="https://www.buzzfeed.com/andrewkaczynski/donald-trump-said-a-lot-of-gross-things-about-women-on-howar?utm_term=.qxAXVAB4Q3#.nxpzQJo490" target="_blank">insulted</a> women for being flat-chested, fat or stupid, “cultivated” that image. Nor do they mention that his misogyny wasn’t just on display while he and Howard “carried on <span>like towel-snapping “bros” in a locker room,” and that it can be found in video and print across the media spectrum.</span> And of course they don’t bother to address the many recent examples of Trump hurling insults at any woman who dares to cross him. Because instead of an explanation (excuse?) for that, <em>The Post</em> chooses to go with it’s all “history” and that there’s a “<span>contrast between Trump’s past and present behavior.” </span></p>

<p><span>Oh, and there’s one more thing <em>The Post </em>article doesn’t mention: That aside from the personal slurs against women that Trump trots out on a regular basis to this very day, his policy positions on women’s issues—anti-choice, anti-Planned Parenthood, anti-equal pay, to name a few—are horrible. But let’s ignore all that, too. </span></p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=vUCVnHOq7Pk:gMO0UuOJBFI:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/vUCVnHOq7Pk" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Barbara Morrill)</author>

<item>
<title>As von Clownstick might say, 'Even a judge can get the Two Amendment wrong. Saad!' GunFAIL CLXXXII</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/IaQxBc85XLE/-As-von-Clownstick-might-say-Even-a-judge-can-get-the-Two-Amendment-wrong-Saad-GunFAIL-CLXXXII</link>
<description><p>Another ugly week, by the numbers. But then, they’re all pretty ugly. Twenty-three people accidentally shot themselves, 12 kids were accidentally shot, nine GunFAIL incidents resulted in fatalities, and seven people accidentally shot family members. And in one rather odd spike, eight people accidentally fired guns while out and about, shopping, dining, or otherwise availing themselves of public services, but five of the eight accidents happened in hotel rooms, with two of the five incidents involving bullets passing through the walls into the next units.</p>

<p>The rest of the week’s GunFAILs included your routine mix of gun range accidents (two), imaginary intruders (two), real intruders who weren’t shot while roommates were accidentally shot instead (one), security guards (one) and law enforcement officers (two) who accidentally fired their weapons, hunting accidents (one), and of course, people who accidentally fired their guns because they were cleaning (or “inspecting”) them while they were still loaded (five).</p>

<p>Plenty of oddities among the GunFAILs this week, too. Out in Idaho, a member of the III%er militia took his 12-year-old daughter with him to the local gun range for a militia meeting, after which someone clearing a weapon accidentally fired a round which ricocheted off a metal table and struck the girl in the stomach. It will surprise no one to learn that the “militia” are no better with their guns than anyone else. Another semi-political GunFAIL gives us our post title this week, thanks to Michigan Court of Appeals Judge Henry Saad getting stopped with a loaded revolver in his luggage at the Detroit Metro Airport. You may remember Saad as one of the two judges <em>not</em> given a vote and eventually confirmed in 2005, following the infamous “Gang of 14” agreement that defused a Republican threat to use the “nuclear option” to eliminate the filibuster on judicial nominations. Heh.</p>

<p>In the “places there shouldn’t be a gun, because problems are just too predictable” category: the Chico State fraternity member who accidentally shot himself in the hand in the Alpha Gamma Rho house, and the woman sleeping in a motel with a gun under her pillow who thought she heard a noise and then accidentally shot herself in the chest while grabbing it.</p>

<p>Lastly, from South Dakota we have the story of the latest armed teacher to accidentally shoot himself, though at least it wasn’t in school this time. It’s unclear from the story whether this third-grade teacher regularly brought the weapon with him to school, but it was allegedly in the pocket of a coat he dropped while at home at 6:20 PM on a Friday night, and he got a 9mm hole from his stomach up through the back of his left shoulder for his trouble. The Bon Homme County Sheriff reassures us that this is “just a freak accident,” though. No need to worry about teachers who carry guns that fire when the coat it’s in drops to the floor. It’s all good from this point on, mathematically speaking. It’s not like a coat can fall twice, right?</p>

<p>Find the full list of nearly 50 GunFAIL mishaps for the week below the fold.</p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=IaQxBc85XLE:d-hI22sThIo:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/IaQxBc85XLE" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (David Waldman)</author>

<item>
<title>The fighting has barely begun for House Republicans over budget, spending bills</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/W6xqf6_6NCU/-The-fighting-has-barely-begun-for-House-Republicans-over-budget-spending-bills</link>
<description><p>Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has a plan for trying to protect the Republican Senate majority this election cycle, even with Donald Trump looming. His big idea is to <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/05/11/1525392/-Mitch-McConnell-s-Trump-gambit-ignore-him-and-he-ll-go-away" title="">move spending bills</a>, making it look like the Senate is functioning like it's supposed to—getting shit done. As usual, McConnell isn't taking into account the depth of the mess that is the House Republican majority. Or the extent to which trying to get spending out of that body is <a href="http://www.bna.com/missed-budget-deadline-n57982070959/" title="">going to become an even more massive fight</a> than it's been so far.</p>

<p>To recap, the Freedom Caucus-types are having buyers' remorse, now reneging on the budget agreement most of them supported last fall. They want to roll back the spending level they all agreed to then, and have refused to allow a budget framework to pass. Now, there's a way for the House to get around having that budget agreement when it comes to appropriations bills—they could "attempt to 'deem' a budget adopted, a path taken every year since the 1974 Budget Act that an actual budget has not been adopted." Even if they do that (and Speaker Paul Ryan has already <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/gop-moderates-budget-mess_us_57040573e4b083f5c6092c20">said</a> he doesn't want to, because he'd need Democrats to help do that and that was the main thing that got his predecessor John Boehner in trouble), they have to agree to rules for each of the spending bills to come to the floor. Appropriations bills are <a href="http://www.brookings.edu/blogs/fixgov/posts/2016/05/10-house-senate-appropriations-fights-reynolds">almost always</a> offered with open amendments and when "appropriations bills come to the floor under open rules, the Rules Committee loses its ability to dictate which amendments are permitted to be offered and thus prevent votes on potentially divisive issues." They could try to close the rule to keep Democrats from offering amendments, but that would still mean the wack-job Freedom-y guys could offer up theirs. And they would be ridiculous.</p>

<p>There's <a href="http://www.bna.com/missed-budget-deadline-n57982070959/" title="">another problem</a> with ignoring both the budget process and the shortcut of "deeming" a budget: "Bypassing both a budget and deeming resolution raises another question: What is the role of the Budget Committee?" You've got this powerful committee—one that Paul Ryan himself rose to prominence through—that would be rendered meaningless. Which brings us to the most absurd thing to happen so far in the 114th Congress.</p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=W6xqf6_6NCU:NtneNy2-oig:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/W6xqf6_6NCU" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Joan McCarter)</author>

<item>
<title>Donald Trump won't be able to have the classiest, most luxurious presidential administration</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/6IOv8xpZ584/-Donald-Trump-won-t-be-able-to-have-the-classiest-most-luxurious-presidential-administration</link>
<description><p>You can say this about Donald Trump: If he becomes president, his administration is not likely to be a replay of the George W. Bush administration, with most top roles filled by retreads from still earlier Republican presidential administrations. That’s because the big names—and plenty of the small ones—in Republican policy <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/donald-trump-administration-transition-222944" target="_blank">don’t want to work for Trump</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
<p>One former Republican official who worked in the Environmental Protection Agency put it this way: “You’d have to worry about your future career and the way you’re perceived in these things. You just kind of think of how he deals with people. Would you really want to work for him?”</p>
</blockquote>

<p>So what’s a Trump administration going to look like if the Paul Wolfowitz types think they’re too good for it?</p>

<blockquote>
<p><span>“The bottom line is Trump will be able to fill these jobs because there is a whole class of people who want these titles so badly it doesn’t matter who is president,” said a former senior George W. Bush administration official. “But these are B- or C-level people. They are honorable, but not very good. The A-level people, and there are not that many of them to begin with, mostly don’t want to work for Trump. He will cut the A-level bench of available policy talent at least in half, if not more.”</span></p>
</blockquote>

<p>You don’t have to praise the big names of the George W. Bush administration to think it would be truly terrifying to see what a B- and C-level administration headed by Donald Trump would look like. </p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=6IOv8xpZ584:W7qYzRKURLY:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/6IOv8xpZ584" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Laura Clawson)</author>
<category>DonaldTrump</category>
<category>Republicans</category>
<guid isPermaLink="false">_1525039</guid>
<pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 16:02:44 +0000</pubDate>

<title>NC school system to allow pepper spray to defend against bathroom intruders—what could go wrong?</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/JyTv0F35Pz0/-NC-school-system-to-allow-pepper-spray-to-defend-against-bathroom-intruders-what-could-go-wrong</link>
<description><p><span>The </span><span>Rowan-Salisbury Board of Education really upped that ante on stupid education policies Tuesday when it decided to allow high school students to carry mace amid these turbulent bathroom times in North Carolina. Rebecca Rider brings us <a href="http://www.salisburypost.com/2016/05/10/board-amends-policies-to-allow-pepper-spray-shaving-razors-on-campuses/#sthash.EG23mDSd.dpuf" target="_blank">part of the sound reasoning</a> for the policy change:</span></p>

<blockquote>
<p><span>Board member Chuck Hughes was in favor of the sprays on campuses, saying that in his mind, they were purely defensive. He also referenced HB2, saying that the sprays might be useful.</span></p>

<p><span>“Depending on how the courts rule on the bathroom issues, it may be a pretty valuable tool to have on the female students if they go to the bathroom, not knowing who may come in,” he said.</span></p>
</blockquote>

<p><span>“Depending on how the courts rule,” huh? You mean, if they decide trans students can use the proper bathrooms? Absolutely, protection is in order! Let’s arm a bunch of pubescent teens who don’t have fully formed brains yet with a weapon and then create a culture of hysteria around their bathroom peers—what could go wrong?</span></p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=JyTv0F35Pz0:-yo_XfyYL40:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/JyTv0F35Pz0" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>

<item>
<title>Senate defeats Cotton's amendment undermining Iran nuclear agreement over 'heavy water' buys</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/D35fWekA_qs/-Senate-defeats-Cotton-s-amendment-undermining-Iran-nuclear-agreement-over-heavy-water-buys</link>
<description><p>Freshman Republican Sen. Tom Cotton of Arkansas has been trying to undermine the Iran nuclear agreement from the get-go. Last year, Cotton wrote—and 46 other senators signed—a letter to Iran’s “supreme leader” and its president saying the deal would not be upheld after President Obama leaves office. Since then, he’s tried other gambits to keep the agreement from happening, or to wreck it after it was signed. These have all failed and now, we’re seeing his latest effort. </p>

<p>Wednesday Cotton failed to get the 60 votes needed for an energy and water appropriations bill amendment to bar the United States from making new purchases of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heavy_water" target="_blank" title="">heavy water</a> from Iran under the nuclear agreement. </p>

<p>It wasn’t the first time Cotton’s effort in this matter has failed. Two Wednesdays ago, the senator’s attempt to get a vote on the amendment to the <span>$37.5 billion </span>appropriations bill—widely seen as a bipartisan effort that could loosen the logjam that has kept such measures from being passed on time in the past few years—caused the bill itself to be defeated when four Republicans joined all the Senate Democrats in shooting it down. <span>The bill includes several national security programs, including the Department of Energy’s oversight of the nation’s nuclear arsenal. </span>Resistance to Cotton’s amendment subsequently blocked the bill two more times, including in a vote this past Monday. </p>

<p><span>As part of the Iran nuclear agreement, Tehran is required to dilute, sell, or dispose of most of its stockpile of heavy water. This is used to moderate some types of nuclear reactors, in the process of making nuclear weapons and for medical and other research. Cotton’s amendment would have blocked the Obama administration’s plan to purchase $8.6 million of heavy water—32 tons worth. The U.S. Department of Energy would store the heavy water at its Oakridge, Tennessee, facility and sell it to universities and other researchers. </span></p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=D35fWekA_qs:K3ckS2Zn9Ks:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/D35fWekA_qs" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Meteor Blades)</author>
<category>Iran</category>
<category>Irannuclearagreement</category>
<category>TomCotton</category>
<guid isPermaLink="false">_1525498</guid>
<pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 19:35:48 +0000</pubDate>
<feedburner:origLink>http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/05/11/1525498/-Senate-defeats-Cotton-s-amendment-undermining-Iran-nuclear-agreement-over-heavy-water-buys</feedburner:origLink></item>
<item>
<title>Spotlight on green news &amp; views: Investigators digging into Exxon denials; Ft. McMurray wildfire</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/aBKBfxiFJzc/-Spotlight-on-green-news-amp-views-Investigators-digging-into-Exxon-denials-Ft-McMurray-wildfire</link>
<description><p>Spotlight on Green News &amp; Views (previously known as the Green Diary Rescue) appears twice a week, on Wednesdays and Saturdays. <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/05/07/1523706/-Spotlight-on-green-news-amp-views-That-coffee-is-made-HOW-grizzlies-at-risk-Alberta-wildfire" title="">Here is the most recent previous Green Spotlight</a>. More than <strong>25,180 </strong>environmentally oriented stories have been rescued to appear in this series since 2006. <u>Inclusion of a story in the Spotlight does not necessarily indicate my agreement with or endorsement of it</u>.</p>

<p class="AlignCenter"><strong>OUTSTANDING GREEN STORIES</strong></p>

<figure class="image-captioned align-right"><img alt="6_16startfish1.JPG" src="http://images.dailykos.com/images/250074/large/6_16startfish1.JPG?1462944787" title="6_16startfish1.JPG">
<figcaption>The seastar known as Pisaster ochraceus.</figcaption>
</figure>

<p><strong>OceanDiver</strong><span> writes—</span><strong><a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/05/11/1525295/-The-Daily-Bucket-news-from-the-oceans" target="_blank">The Daily Bucket - news from the oceans</a></strong><span>: </span><span>“</span><span>Oceanographers from the University of Georgia revealed an unexpected 600 mile-long deepwater biogenic reef off the mouth of the Amazon. They have brought up samples along its length, mapping a variety of ecosystems. One reason no one expected to find a reef there is because it is deep and dark, the topmost portions 50 meters down where light rarely penetrates. Coral reef builders require sunlight for their photosynthetic endosymbionts, which is why living corals are shallow enough to snorkel over. T</span><span>he </span><a href="http://advances.sciencemag.org/content/advances/2/4/e1501252.full" target="_blank">published report</a><span> describes the bulk of the reef’s builders to be “turned off” but the legacy structure, deep now after changes in sea level, provides a substrate for a diverse series of ecosystems that include sponges, brittle stars, tubeworms, urchins, and many fish. </span><span>The other reason a reef was considered unlikely here is that the Amazon River constantly pours out tons of sediment and fresh water, both reef killers. Evidently the fresh water stratifies, staying on top of the oceanic saltwater for the most part, and the extreme currents blow the sediment away from the reef so the creatures there are not smothered. Coralline algal species continue to build on the reef, though at a much slower rate than coral animals and the overall diversity of the deep reef is lower than shallow coral reefs, but this gigantic structure provides a </span><a href="http://news.nationalgeographic.com/2016/04/220416-Amazon-coral-reef-Brazil-ocean-river-fish/" target="_blank">refuge for many species</a><span>. It’s also an important nursery for juvenile fish and lobster. Unfortunately, the Brazilian government has sold 80 leases for oil-drilling in the area, two of which are active directly on top of the newly discovered reef.</span><span>”</span><strong> </strong></p>

<p><strong>kristie kusch </strong><span>writes—</span><strong><a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/05/08/1524504/-Cherry-Point-is-not-a-Bowl-of-Cherries" target="_blank" title="">Cherry Point is not a Bowl of Cherries</a></strong><span>: </span><span>“</span><span>I live in the Pacific Northwest, home to wildlife and landscape that can’t be found anywhere else, but now, our way of life is threatened by the specter of coal. </span><span>Wyoming is a coal state, Montana is a coal state, North Dakota is a fracturing technology state, the gulf of Mexico and the Alaskan Peninsula are endangered by oil and liquid natural gas extraction, and now the Pacific Northwest is falling under the gavel in the quest for more environmentally dangerous practices, leading to climate change with a proposed coal terminal. </span><span>This project is known as the Gateway Terminal, incorporating wharves that would move up to 48 million tons of coal a year. For perspective, that is enough to cover 80 acres in 5 open stockpiles, by water, each 2,100 feet long and up to 70 feet high, accomplished by utilizing ships, many nearly 3 football fields long and bound mostly for Asia and setting sail every 18 hours. Cherry Point is already home to oil refineries that produce 140,000 barrels of oil a day, providing the west coast with most of its oil and gas supply, and now, is under threat of expansion for additional pipelines that could produce up to 800,000 barrels of oil a day. It also has an aluminum smelting plant, leading to more pollution of an already endangered oceanic gateway. The proposed expansion of the Gateway Terminal would make it the fourth largest terminal in the country and lead to environmental degradation and an encroachment on tribal treaty rites.</span></p><div class="feedflare">

<item>
<title>North Carolina Sen. Richard Burr: Let's give Donald Trump three Supreme Court nominees!</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/gM5eIKKul_4/-Richard-Burr-Let-s-give-Donald-Trump-three-Supreme-Court-nominees</link>
<description><figure class="image-captioned width-sm"><a href="https://secure.actblue.com/contribute/page/dkfordr?refcode=20160511JM1thermometer&amp;tandembox=show" title=""><img alt="Goal Thermometer" src="https://secure.actblue.com/x/object/actblue-badges/page/dkfordr/thermometer/dark.png"></a>

<figcaption></figcaption>
</figure>

<p>Sen. Richard Burr must have a lot of faith in voter suppression in his home state of North Carolina, because the Republican who is up for re-election this year is now <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/richard-burr-donald-trump_us_57321d4fe4b0bc9cb0483e87">fully embracing</a> Donald Trump as the guy who should be picking Supreme Court nominees—however many might come up in his tenure.</p>

<blockquote>Sen. Richard Burr (R-N.C.) endorsed the whole idea of a President Donald Trump on Saturday. Speaking at the annual North Carolina GOP State Convention, Burr said he looked forward to supporting Trump’s appointment of not just one, but three conservative Supreme Court justices.
<p>“It is absolutely crucial to our future that we elect a Republican that’s going to be Donald Trump, and we’re going to be the ones that put three Supreme Court justices in office,” Burr said.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>That's some pretty big talk from Burr. Of course, it <em>did</em> happen at the state Republican convention, where he was pretty much surrounded by Republicans. When it comes to actually appearing with Trump, in perhaps not-so-friendly crowds, he's <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/05/09/1524689/-Richard-Burr-all-in-for-Trump-as-long-as-he-doesn-t-have-to-campaign-with-him">a little less enthusiastic</a>, leaving it simply at "I'm going to be focused on my own re-election."</p>

<p>This was supposed to be a safe seat, but in the <a href="http://www.publicpolicypolling.com/main/2016/04/north-carolina-senate-race-remains-close.html" title="">latest PPP poll</a>, he's leading Democrat Deborah Ross by just four points, 40-36. And while there isn't any state breakdown in PPP's polling on <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/05/09/1524714/-Americans-really-don-t-like-the-idea-of-a-Trump-Supreme-Court" title="">Trump and the Supreme Court</a>, overall voters don't have the same trust in Trump that Burr has. At all. Because 29 percent of Republicans don't want him picking the next justice, much less a third of the court.</p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=gM5eIKKul_4:irLMPXdfWeU:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/gM5eIKKul_4" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Joan McCarter)</author>

<item>
<title>Mitch McConnell's Trump gambit: Ignore him and he'll go away?</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/-tyjWFDsWdk/-Mitch-McConnell-s-Trump-gambit-ignore-him-and-he-ll-go-away</link>
<description><p>Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell appears to be operating under the assumption that "regular order"—the Senate doing stuff like passing spending bills—will be enough to make people forget that the Republican Party’s standard-bearer is Donald Trump. So he's got the Senate working on <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/mitch-mcconnell-donald-trump-223029">spending bills</a> that will likely falter in the House, and at the same time get bogged down by his own Republicans on the floor.</p>

<blockquote>With his narrow majority under siege in November, McConnell is digging through the procedural playbook to try and pass annual appropriations bills that have been neglected for 22 years. They face a steep path to becoming law with Sen. Tom Cotton (R-Ark.) proposing a tough amendment on Iran and House conservatives reluctant to deal with fiscal legislation that, in their view, simply spends too much.
<p>But McConnell wants to prove Democrats wrong and show that Republicans can keep Congress running more smoothly than they ever did.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>There's a few problems there for McConnell—Sen. Cotton, for one. Ted Cruz is back now, too, and there's little reason to believe he'll decide to play nice. House Republicans are another problem. They can't come to any agreement on spending and are very unlikely to actually pass any of these bills McConnell has the Senate laboring over.</p>

<p>But the primary problem for McConnell in trying to make like the Senate is doing its job? Ignoring a Supreme Court vacancy! Sen. Brian Schatz (D-HI) says it all: </p>

<blockquote>"If they're going to say: Yes, they support Donald Trump and they support his appointing the next Supreme Court justice, but on the other hand they moved a [spending] bill? I look forward to the opportunity to prosecute that case with the voters."</blockquote>

<p>Indeed.</p>

<p><a href="https://secure.actblue.com/contribute/page/upgradethesenate2016?refcode=20160511JM1?tandembox=show" title="">Please donate $3 today to help turn the Senate blue. The future of the Supreme Court depends on it.</a></p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=-tyjWFDsWdk:JEkJig0YK_w:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/-tyjWFDsWdk" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>

<item>
<title>North Carolina HB2 dispute comes down to ’sex’ discrimination, which was apparently laughable in '64</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/H0ST8_CAiO4/-North-Carolina-HB2-dispute-comes-down-to-sex-discrimination-which-was-apparently-laughable-in-64</link>
<description><p><span>The question at the heart of <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/05/09/1524805/-Justice-Department-sues-North-Carolina-to-block-HB2-Lynch-calls-it-state-sponsored-discrimination" target="_blank">the showdown</a> between the federal government and North Carolina over the state’s HB2 law is whether Congress intended “sex” discrimination to cover transgender Americans or “gender identity” when it passed the Civl Rights Act of 1964. But it seems Congress didn’t spend a whole lot of time pondering what would, in fact, be covered by the term because members were too amused by how preposterous the notion of “sex” discrimination was, <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/us/transgender-fight-in-north-carolina-may-hinge-on-if-a-1964-law-applies.html?hp&amp;action=click&amp;pgtype=Homepage&amp;clickSource=story-heading&amp;module=second-column-region%C2%AEion=top-news&amp;WT.nav=top-news&amp;_r=0" target="_blank" title="">reports</a> the <em>New York Times</em>.</span></p>

<blockquote>
<p><span>The word sex made it into the bill at the last minute, almost accidentally. It was inserted only after the drafting and congressional hearings, when the bill went to the House floor. Representative Howard W. Smith, a Virginia Democrat who opposed the bill, introduced an amendment adding sex discrimination, prompting laughter from his colleagues, who mockingly offered other suggested additions.</span></p>

<p><span>Despite speculation that Mr. Smith meant to weaken support for the bill — he said his concern for women was sincere — his amendment passed, and so did the act. The rights of transgender people never came up.</span></p>
</blockquote>

<p><span>Oh, so very <em>Mad Men</em>, no? Anyway, turns out sex discrimination is a real thing. Who knew?</span></p>

<blockquote>
<p><span>The 1964 law’s ban on sex discrimination was applied narrowly at first, but the Supreme Court broadened it in a series of rulings saying that sex discrimination includes sexual harassment, that the law protects men as well as women, and that discrimination against a person for not adhering to sex stereotypes in appearance is sex discrimination.</span></p>
</blockquote><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=H0ST8_CAiO4:LwB5Yo4lYXk:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/H0ST8_CAiO4" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Kerry Eleveld)</author>

<category>LGBTQ</category>

<category>transrights</category>

<item>
<title>Investigators: Fire that caused 2013 explosion at Texas fertilizer plant was deliberately set</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/kVRWVYqPT_M/-Investigators-Fire-that-caused-2013-explosion-at-Texas-fertilizer-plant-was-deliberately-set</link>
<description><p>The West, Texas, fertilizer plant explosion that killed 15 people and wounded 200 others has been determined to have been the result of a fire <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2016/05/west-texas-explosion/482343/?utm_source=atltw" title="">that was deliberately set</a>.</p>

<blockquote>“This fire was a criminal act,” Robert Elder, the special agent in charge of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF), said at a news conference.</blockquote>

<p>The ATF says that there have been no arrests, and have put up <a href="https://twitter.com/cbs11jack/status/730443820463071232" title="">a $50,000 reward</a> for information that could help identify the perpetrator(s).</p>

<p>Investigators aren't saying what evidence they found that led them to believe the fire was intentionally set, but the results were catastrophic. Threadbare Texas safety regulations meant the plant, which in its recent history had housed as much as 270 tons of explosive ammonium nitrate at one time, <a href="https://stateimpact.npr.org/texas/2013/04/22/after-west-fertilizer-explosion-concerns-over-safety-regulation-and-zoning/" title="">had few sprinklers, no fire barriers, and an inadequate safety plan</a>. The plant was located next to a school, an apartment building, a nursing home, and other residences. Most of the fatalities were first responders who arrived at the scene to fight the initial fire but <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2014/4/22/1293857/-A-year-after-Texas-fertilizer-explosion-safety-regulations-are-no-stronger" title="">didn't know</a> that chemicals at the plant posed an explosion risk.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/23/us/lack-of-oversight-and-regulations-blamed-in-texas-chemical-explosion.html?ref=us&amp;_r=1">An investigation</a> concluded that the explosion itself "was preventable," and "resulted from the failure of a company to take the necessary steps to avert a preventable fire and explosion and from the inability of federal, state and local regulatory agencies to identify a serious hazard and correct it."</p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=kVRWVYqPT_M:7MfiAH1zK6k:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/kVRWVYqPT_M" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Hunter)</author>

<category>Safety</category>
<category>Texas</category>
<category>West</category>

<item>
<title>Another Koch ad attack on a Democrat, another backfire</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/G4d-GfSfYzg/-Another-Koch-ad-attack-on-a-Democrat-another-backfire</link>
<description><figure class="image-captioned width-sm"><a href="https://secure.actblue.com/contribute/page/dkforccm?refcode=20160511JM1thermometer?tandembox=show"><img alt="Goal Thermometer" src="https://secure.actblue.com/x/object/actblue-badges/page/dkforccm/thermometer/dark.png"></a>

<figcaption></figcaption>
</figure>

<p>All that <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/05/10/1525125/-The-silver-lining-for-Republican-senators-running-with-Trump-more-Koch-and-Rove-money-for-them">Koch money not going to Donald Trump</a> is being spent on Senate races, including against Catherine Cortez Masto, the Democrat who hopes to replace outgoing Sen. Harry Reid in Nevada. The Kochs <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/05/06/1523937/-Kochs-take-aim-at-Nevada-Senate-candidate-Catherine-Cortez-Masto" title="">are spending more than $1 million</a> running an ad against her alleging that she used fancy-pants lawyers to sue Bank of America for foreclosure fraud, and then took campaign contributions from those lawyers. The Kochs say this was a "cozy relationship."</p>

<p>The <em>Las Vegas Review-Journal</em> <a href="http://www.reviewjournal.com/opinion/columns-blogs/steve-sebelius/no-cozy-relationship-settlement-case-ag-catherine-cortez-masto" title="">says this was Masto doing her job</a>. Because that outside firm she hired "successfully forced one of the largest banks in the country to pay the state millions to compensate for alleged wrongdoing." That settlement was $38 million. </p>

<p>Embarrassingly enough for the Kochs, the Republican they're boosting in the race <a href="http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/housing/nevada-joins-states-25-billion-foreclosure-abuse-deal" title="">is on the record</a> touting the settlement.</p>

<blockquote>Rep. Joe Heck, R-Nev., said he is "happy to see that an agreement was reached. At a time when Nevada families are struggling the most to make ends meet, I have high hopes that this settlement will provide them much needed relief."</blockquote>

<p>That's, of course, once the settlement was reached. While the whole mess was going on Heck was pretty uninvolved, <a href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2016/05/04/tv-ads-trash-nevada-senate-candidate-catherine-cortez-masto/83928458/">saying the crisis</a> was just "a blip on the radar." A blip that forced thousands of Nevadans out of their homes and almost took down the global economy. Good priorities Heck has there.</p><div class="feedflare">
<a href="http://feeds.dailykos.com/~ff/dailykos/index?a=G4d-GfSfYzg:D7iiUpd0oQU:H0mrP-F8Qgo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/dailykos/index?d=H0mrP-F8Qgo" border="0"></img></a>
</div><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/dailykos/index/~4/G4d-GfSfYzg" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
<author>rss@dailykos.com (Joan McCarter)</author>
<category>CatherineCortezMasto</category>
<category>JoeHeck</category>
<category>KochBrothers</category>
<category>Nevada</category>
<category>NV-Sen</category>
<guid isPermaLink="false">_1525476</guid>
<pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 17:41:46 +0000</pubDate>
<feedburner:origLink>http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/05/11/1525476/-Another-Koch-ad-attack-on-a-Democrat-another-backfire</feedburner:origLink></item>
<item>
<title>Midday open thread: Big donors contribute big $$ to SuperPacs; wagering on a Trump loss</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/S-lFBTe3dhI/-Midday-open-thread-Big-donors-contribute-big-to-SuperPacs-wagering-on-a-Trump-loss</link>
<description><p>Today’s <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/blog/Comics" target="_blank">comic</a>by Matt Bors is <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/stories/2016/5/11/1525121/-Cartoon-The-grueling-primary" target="_blank">The grueling primary</a>:</p>

<div class="align-center">
<figure class="image-captioned"><img alt="Cartoon by Matt Bors -- A gruelng primary" src="http://images.dailykos.com/images/250062/large/teaser.png?1462942050" title="Cartoon by Matt Bors -- A gruelng primary">
<figcaption></figcaption>
</figure>
</div>

<p><strong>• </strong><a href="http://ecowatch.com/2016/05/11/honey-bee-losses/" target="_blank">Beekeepers lost 44 percent of honey bee colonies in 2015:</a> The continuing losses of honey bees took an upward turn last year. T<span>he Bee Informed Partnership, together with the Apiary Inspectors of America and the U.S. Department of Agriculture reported the loss in </span><span>the total number of colonies managed. That 44 percent is close to the highest annual loss over the past six years and are seen as exceeding the level thought to be sustainable by the beekeeping industry.</span> Among the suspected causes for the alarming bee colony declines is exposure to a class of <span>insecticides known as neonicotinoids. Many states, cities, universities and businesses have passed measures to restrict use of these insecticides because the EPA has delayed doing so. Said Tiffany Finck-Haynes, food futures campaigner with </span><a href="http://www.foe.org/" target="_blank">Friends of the Earth</a>: “These honey bee losses reinforce what sciences continues to tell us; we must take immediate action to restrict pesticides contributing to bee declines,”  “The longer we wait, the worse the situation becomes. If we do not suspend <a href="http://ecowatch.com/?s=neonicotinoid">neonicotinoid pesticides</a> immediately, we risk losing our beekeepers and harming important ecosystem functions upon which our food supply depends.”</p>

<p>• <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/politics/superpac-donors-2016/" target="_blank">Big donors contribute big money to SuperPacs—$709 million so far</a>: Check out the individuals or families that have contributed the most: Robert Mercer—$17.2 million; Tom Steyer—17 million; the Wilks family—$15.3 million; Maurice “Hank” Greenberg—$15.1 million; George Soros—$12 million; Elizabeth &amp; Richard Uihlein—$11.1 million; Paul Singer—$10.4 million; Marilyn &amp; James Simons—$10.13 million; Toby Neugebauer—$10.1 million; Ronald Cameron—$8.8 million.</p>

<p>• <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/science/kepler-planets-nasa.html?_r=0" target="_blank">Poor Pluto. Kepler space probe has catalogued another 1,284 planets outside our solar system</a>. That brings the total number of exoplanets the spacecraft has found to more than 2,000: </p>

<blockquote>
<p><span>All of them orbit stars in a patch of sky on the Cygnus-Lyra border, where Kepler, launched in 2009, spent four years staring at 150,000 stars looking for the characteristic dimming when planets crossed their faces, until its </span><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/19/science/space/new-plan-for-a-disabled-ke...">pointing system broke</a><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/19/science/space/new-plan-for-a-disabled-ke..."> down</a><span> and the team had to develop a new observing strategy. Since then, Kepler has identified some 4,700 possible planets, and more keep being found.</span></p>
</blockquote>

<p>• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/10/kern-county-california-sexual-assault-police-settlement" target="_blank" title="">Loose-lipped attorneys may have risked million-dollar settlement in sexual assault case</a>: The settlement was awarded to a woman sexually assaulted by a sheriff’s deputy in Kern County, California. But the settlement could be withdrawn because attorneys for the woman violated its terms by disclosing them to the media. The case is the second time in the past week that a police misconduct lawsuit was settled in Kern County for seven figures. Law enforcement is the county is the deadliest in the United States, according to a <em>Guardian</em> newspaper investigation.</p>

<p>• <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qvBf6WBatk0" target="_blank">Here’s the trailer for Civilization VI, the latest entry in the strategy game series.</a></p>

<p>• <a href="http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2016/05/don-blankenship-heading-prison-his-allies-still-buy-judicial-elections-west-virgini" target="_blank">Coal mine owner begins prison term Thursday, but his allies bought a judicial election Tuesday:</a> </p>

<blockquote>
<p>West Virginia coal baron Don Blankenship is <a href="https://twitter.com/Kenwardjr/status/730153234728427520" target="_blank">slated</a> to start a one-year prison sentence on Thursday after being convicted of conspiracy to violate mine safety rules in the lead-up to a massive explosion in one of the mines run by the company he led, Massey Energy. But his legacy still hangs over West Virginia politics.</p>

<p>On Tuesday, his allies helped elect a business-friendly justice, Beth Walker, to the state Supreme Court by pouring at least $2.5 million into the race, according to the Brennan Center for Justice. It's a strange ending to a story that began 12 years ago, when Blankenship spent $3 million to unseat a liberal justice and replace him with a Charleston attorney named Brent Benjamin, who went on to vote to overturn a $50 million judgment against Massey Energy.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>• <a href="http://rewire.news/article/2016/05/11/chicago-dunkin-donuts-wage-theft-case/" target="_blank">Lawsuit claims Chicago-area Dunkin’ Donuts stole workers wages</a>: Two employees of the local franchise filed a suit say that the owner and director of operations had, over a decade, failed to pay employees for overtime and had routinely taken money workers’ paycheck to cover cash register shortages without getting workers’ permission to do so as state law requires.</p>

<p>• <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/05/the-people-who-still-bet-trump-wont-win-the-nomination/482148/" target="_blank">Some people are still betting Trump will lose</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
<p><span>On PredictIt, a betting exchange that specializes in political contests, thousands of gamblers would still give Trump </span><a href="https://www.predictit.org/Market/1233/Who-will-win-the-2016-Republican-presidential-nomination" title="">a seven percent chance</a><span> of flaming out before officially clinching the nomination in Cleveland. The odds are </span><a href="https://www.betfair.com/exchange/plus/#/politics/market/1.107664938">about the same</a><span> on Betfair, a British competitor. [...]</span></p>

<p><span>The rules of the PredictIt market state that bets won’t be paid until the conclusion of the Republican National Convention. The payoff has nothing to do with delegates, of which Trump has plenty, or the billionaire’s position in the polls, which is obviously strong. That 7-percent slack, then, encompasses any number of the unlikely-but-still-possible ways Trump could lose the nomination: a bizarre parliamentary maneuver in Cleveland, a sudden illness, a world-ending asteroid impact.</span></p>
</blockquote>

<p>• On <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/stories/2016/5/11/1525414/-Daily-Kos-Radio-s-KITM-podcast-AUDIO-Kagro-in-the-Morning-Wednesday-May-11-2016" target="_blank" title="">today’s <em>Kagro in the Morning</em> show</a>, <strong>Greg Dworkin</strong> helps sort out WV and the role of race in… the race. Hairspray von Clownstick taps Rudy Gi911iani. <strong>Joan McCarter</strong> discovers that the Gop budget #FAIL may be bigger than anyone ever imagined. The Zodiac returns to the Senate to help them do nothing.</p>

<item>
<title>Trump's team blames 'database error' for making prominent white nationalist a delegate, but ...</title>
<link>http://feeds.dailykos.com/~r/dailykos/index/~3/aQhpueDnx8A/-Trump-s-team-blames-database-error-for-making-prominent-white-nationalist-a-delegate-but</link>
<description><p>The news that Donald Trump's campaign had tapped the leader of one of the most prominent white nationalist groups in the nation to be <a href="http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2016/05/donald-trump-white-nationalist-afp-delegate-california" title="">one of its California delegates</a> was dismissed yesterday by the Trump camp as a "database error." Surely, countless campaigns have faced this problem and can attest to how hard it can be to purge all the white supremacists from your campaign databases—they tend to scurry up into the cracks and corners and you have to poke at them with a broom to dislodge them, and as like as not that just makes them fall into some other spreadsheet, anything from <em>O</em><em>ffice Birthdays</em> to <em>Potential Vice President Picks</em>.</p>

<p>It must have been one persistent database error, in this case, because the very day before <em>Mother Jones</em> published its story William Johnson was not just still in the database, but was getting helpful advice from Trump's delegate managers on <a href="http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2016/05/trump-white-nationalist-california-delegate-response-email-pledge-database-error" title="">how to complete the process</a>.</p>

<blockquote>Although the Trump campaign blamed a "database error" for including Johnson as a delegate, the campaign corresponded with him personally just over 24 hours ago. Trump's California delegate coordinator, Katie Lagomarsino, sent Johnson a congratulatory email on Monday, and when he asked for clarification about how to send his completed pledge form back to the campaign, she replied.</blockquote>

<p>Looks like the infestation is pretty bad. You may need to reformat your campaign.</p>

<p>While Johnson says he'll resign if the campaign asks him to, the ABC journalist who profiled Johnson in March for a piece on Trump-supporting white nationalists (because that is a thing this year) notes that <a href="https://twitter.com/CandaceSmith_/status/730195221653360640" title="">the deadline has passed</a> for removing him as a delegate. So ... oops?</p>

<p>There you go. Oh yes, we can all have great confidence that Donald J. Trump will bring some much-needed basic competence to American governance. You can just smell the genius wafting from his offices.</p><div class="feedflare">
